paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
The clock hath stricken three.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
The clock struck three.

paragraphs.original:
TREBONIUS
'Tis time to part.
paragraphs.translated:
TREBONIUS
It's time to leave.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
But it is doubtful yet
Whether Caesar will come forth today or no.
For he is superstitious grown of late,
Quite from the main opinion he held once
Of fantasy, of dreams and ceremonies.
It may be, these apparent prodigies,
The unaccustomed terror of this night,
And the persuasion of his augurers
May hold him from the Capitol today.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
But we still don't know whether Caesar will go out in public today or not, because he's become superstitious lately, a complete turnaround from when he used to have such a bad opinion of fortune-tellers, dream interpreters, and ritual mumbo-jumbo. It might happen that these strange signs, the unusual terror of this night, and the urgings of his fortune-tellers will keep him away from the Capitol today.

paragraphs.original:
DECIUS
Never fear that. If he be so resolved,
I can o'ersway him. For he loves to hear
That unicorns may be betrayed with trees,
And bears with glasses, elephants with holes,
Lions with toils, and men with flatterers.
But when I tell him he hates flatterers,
He says he does, being then most flatterèd.
Let me work.
For I can give his humor the true bent,
And I will bring him to the Capitol.
paragraphs.translated:
DECIUS
Don't worry about that. If he's reluctant, I can convince him. He loves to hear me tell him how men can be snared by flatterers, just like unicorns can be captured in trees, elephants in holes, and lions with nets. When I tell him he hates flatterers, he agrees, just at the moment when I'm flattering him the most.
Let me work on him. I can put him in the right mood, and I'll bring him to the Capitol.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Nay, we will all of us be there to fetch him.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
No, we'll all go there to bring him.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
By the eighth hour. Is that the uttermost?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
By eight o'clock. Is that the latest we can do it?

paragraphs.original:
CINNA
Be that the uttermost, and fail not then.
paragraphs.translated:
CINNA
Let's make that the latest, but be sure to get there before then.

paragraphs.original:
METELLUS
Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard,
Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey.
I wonder none of you have thought of him.
paragraphs.translated:
METELLUS
Caius Ligarius doesn't like Caesar, who berated him for speaking well of Pompey. I wonder that none of you thought about getting his support.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Now, good Metellus, go along by him.
He loves me well, and I have given him reasons.
Send him but hither and I'll fashion him.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Good Metellus, go to him now. He likes me, and I've given him good reason to. Just send him here, and I'll persuade him.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
The morning comes upon 's. We'll leave you, Brutus.
 - And, friends, disperse yourselves. But all remember
What you have said, and show yourselves true Romans.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
The morning is approaching. We'll leave, Brutus. Friends, go your separate ways. But all of you, remember what you've said and prove yourselves true Romans.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily.
Let not our looks put on our purposes,
But bear it as our Roman actors do,
With untired spirits and formal constancy.
And so good morrow to you every one.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Good gentlemen, look like you're rested and happy. Don't let our faces betray our plans. Instead, carry yourselves like Roman actors, with cheerful spirits and well-composed faces. And so, good morning to all of you.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt. Manet BRUTUS
BRUTUS
paragraphs.translated:
Everyone except BRUTUS exits.
BRUTUS

paragraphs.original:
Boy! Lucius! - Fast asleep? It is no matter.
Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber.
Thou hast no figures nor no fantasies,
Which busy care draws in the brains of men.
Therefore thou sleep'st so sound.
paragraphs.translated: Boy! Lucius! Fast asleep? Well, enjoy the sweetness of deep sleep. Your brain isn't stuffed with the strange shapes and fantasies that come to men who are overwhelmed by worries. That's why you sleep so soundly.

paragraphs.original:
Enter PORTIA
PORTIA
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA enters.
PORTIA

paragraphs.original:
PORTIA
Brutus, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA
Brutus, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Portia, what mean you? Wherefore rise you now?
It is not for your health thus to commit
Your weak condition to the raw, cold morning.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Portia, what are you doing awake? It isn't good for your health to expose your weak body to the raw, cold morning.

paragraphs.original:
PORTIA
Nor for yours neither. Y' have ungently, Brutus,
Stole from my bed. And yesternight, at supper,
You suddenly arose and walked about,
Musing and sighing, with your arms across,
And when I asked you what the matter was,
You stared upon me with ungentle looks.
I urged you further, then you scratched your head
And too impatiently stamped with your foot.
Yet I insisted; yet you answered not,
But with an angry wafture of your hand
Gave sign for me to leave you. So I did,
Fearing to strengthen that impatience
Which seemed too much enkindled, and withal
Hoping it was but an effect of humor,
Which sometime hath his hour with every man.
It will not let you eat nor talk nor sleep,
And could it work so much upon your shape
As it hath much prevailed on your condition,
I should not know you, Brutus. Dear my lord,
Make me acquainted with your cause of grief.
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA
It's not good for your health, either. You rudely snuck out of bed. And last night at dinner, you got up abruptly and paced back and forth with your arms crossed, brooding and sighing, and when I asked you what was the matter, you gave me a dirty look. I asked you again, and you scratched your head and stamped your foot impatiently. I still insisted on knowing what the matter was, but you wouldn't answer me, instead giving me an angry wave of your hand and telling me to leave you alone. So I left, afraid of further provoking anger that was already inflamed but still hoping this was merely moodiness, which everyone is affected by once in awhile. Your strange mood won't let you eat or talk or sleep. If it had changed your outward appearance as much as it has affected you on the inside, I wouldn't even be able to recognize you, Brutus. My dear lord, tell me what's bothering you.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
I am not well in health, and that is all.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
I'm not feeling well - that's all.

paragraphs.original:
PORTIA
Brutus is wise, and were he not in health,
He would embrace the means to come by it.
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA
You're smart, though, and if you were sick, you'd take what you needed to get better.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Why, so I do. Good Portia, go to bed.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
I'm doing so. Good Portia, go to bed.

paragraphs.original:
PORTIA
Is Brutus sick? And is it physical
To walk unbracèd and suck up the humors
Of the dank morning? What, is Brutus sick,
And will he steal out of his wholesome bed,
To dare the vile contagion of the night
And tempt the rheumy and unpurgèd air
To add unto his sickness? No, my Brutus.
You have some sick offense within your mind,
Which by the right and virtue of my place
I ought to know of.
(kneels) And upon my knees
(kneels)
I charm you, by my once-commended beauty,
By all your vows of love and that great vow
Which did incorporate and make us one
That you unfold to me, your self, your half,
Why you are heavy, and what men tonight
Have had to resort to you. For here have been
Some six or seven who did hide their faces
Even from darkness.
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA
Are you sick? And is it healthy to walk uncovered and breathe in the dampness of the morning? You're sick, yet you sneak out of your warm bed and let the humid and disease-infested air make you sicker? No, my Brutus, you have some sickness within your mind, which by virtue of my position I deserve to know about. (she kneels) And on my knees, I urge you, by my once-praised beauty, by all your vows of love and that great vow of marriage which made the two of us one person, that you should reveal to me, who is one half of yourself, why you're troubled and what men have visited you tonight. For there were six or seven men here, who hid their faces even in the darkness.
(she kneels)

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Kneel not, gentle Portia.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Don't kneel, noble Portia.

paragraphs.original:
PORTIA
(rising) I should not need if you were gentle, Brutus.
(rising)
Within the bond of marriage, tell me, Brutus,
Is it excepted I should know no secrets
That appertain to you? Am I yourself
But, as it were, in sort or limitation,
To keep with you at meals, comfort your bed,
And talk to you sometimes?
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA
(getting up) I wouldn't need to if you were acting nobly. Tell me, Brutus, as your wife, aren't I supposed to be told the secrets that concern you? Am I part of you only in a limited sense - I get to have dinner with you, sleep with you, and talk to you sometimes?
(getting up)

paragraphs.original:
Dwell I but in the suburbs
Of your good pleasure? If it be no more,
Portia is Brutus' harlot, not his wife.
paragraphs.translated: Is my place only on the outskirts of your happiness? If it's nothing more than that, then I'm your whore, not your wife.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
You are my true and honorable wife,
As dear to me as are the ruddy drops
That visit my sad heart.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
You're my true and honorable wife, as dear to me as the blood that runs through my sad heart.

paragraphs.original:
PORTIA
If this were true, then should I know this secret.
I grant I am a woman, but withal
A woman that Lord Brutus took to wife.
I grant I am a woman, but withal
A woman well-reputed, Cato's daughter.
Think you I am no stronger than my sex,
Being so fathered and so husbanded?
Tell me your counsels. I will not disclose 'em.
I have made strong proof of my constancy,
Giving myself a voluntary wound
Here in the thigh. Can I bear that with patience,
And not my husband's secrets?
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA
If that were true, then I'd know your secret. I admit I'm only a woman, but nevertheless I'm the woman Lord Brutus took for his wife. I admit I'm only a woman, but I'm still a woman from a noble family - I'm Cato's daughter. Do you really think I'm no stronger than the rest of my sex, with such a father and such a husband? Tell me your secrets. I won't betray them. I've proved my trustworthiness by giving myself a voluntary wound here in my thigh. If I can bear that pain, then I can bear my husband's secrets.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
O ye gods,
Render me worthy of this noble wife!
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Oh, gods, make me worthy of this noble wife!

paragraphs.original: Knock within
paragraphs.translated: A knocking sound offstage.

paragraphs.original:
Hark, hark! One knocks. Portia, go in awhile.
And by and by thy bosom shall partake
The secrets of my heart.
All my engagements I will construe to thee,
All the charactery of my sad brows.
Leave me with haste.
paragraphs.translated: Listen! Someone knocks. Portia, go inside awhile, and soon enough you'll share the secrets of my heart. I'll explain all that I have committed to do and all the reasons for my sad face. Leave me quickly.

paragraphs.original:
Exit PORTIA
PORTIA
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA exits.
PORTIA

paragraphs.original: Lucius, who's that knocking?
paragraphs.translated: Lucius, who's that knocking?

paragraphs.original:
Enter LUCIUS and LIGARIUS
LUCIUS
LIGARIUS
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS and LIGARIUS enter. Ligarius wears a cloth wrapped around his head, indicating that he's sick.
LUCIUS
LIGARIUS

paragraphs.original:
LUCIUS
He is a sick man that would speak with you.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS
Here's a sick man who wants to speak with you.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Caius Ligarius, that Metellus spake of. - 
Boy, stand aside. - Caius Ligarius, how?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
It's Caius Ligarius, whom Metellus spoke of. Boy, stand aside. Caius Ligarius! How are you?

paragraphs.original:
LIGARIUS
Vouchsafe good morrow from a feeble tongue.
paragraphs.translated:
LIGARIUS
Please accept my feeble "good morning."

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
O, what a time have you chose out, brave Caius,
To wear a kerchief! Would you were not sick!
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Oh, what a time you've chosen to be sick, brave Caius! How I wish you felt better!

paragraphs.original:
LIGARIUS
I am not sick if Brutus have in hand
Any exploit worthy the name of honor.
paragraphs.translated:
LIGARIUS
I'm not sick if you've prepared some honorable exploit for me.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Such an exploit have I in hand, Ligarius,
Had you a healthful ear to hear of it.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Indeed, I would have such an exploit for you, Ligarius, if you were healthy enough to hear it.

paragraphs.original:
LIGARIUS
(removes his kerchief)
(removes his kerchief)
By all the gods that Romans bow before,
I here discard my sickness! Soul of Rome,
Brave son derived from honorable loins,
Thou, like an exorcist, hast conjured up
My mortifièd spirit. Now bid me run,
And I will strive with things impossible,
Yea, get the better of them. What's to do?
paragraphs.translated:
LIGARIUS
(takes off his head covering) By all the gods that Romans worship, I hereby throw off my sickness! Soul of Rome! Brave son of honorable ancestors! You've conjured up my deadened spirit like an exorcist. Now say the word, and I will tackle all kinds of impossible things, and succeed too. What is there to do?
(takes off his head covering)

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
A piece of work that will make sick men whole.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
A deed that will make sick men healthy.

paragraphs.original:
LIGARIUS
But are not some whole that we must make sick?
paragraphs.translated:
LIGARIUS
But aren't there some healthy men whom we have to make sick?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
That must we also. What it is, my Caius,
I shall unfold to thee as we are going
To whom it must be done.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
That too. My dear Caius, I'll explain the task at hand to you as we walk toward the man we must do it to.

paragraphs.original:
LIGARIUS
Set on your foot,
And with a heart new-fired I follow you,
To do I know not what. But it sufficeth
That Brutus leads me on.
paragraphs.translated:
LIGARIUS
Start walking, and with an energized heart, I'll follow you - to what, I don't know, but I'm satisfied, simply knowing that Brutus leads me.

paragraphs.original: Thunder
paragraphs.translated: Thunder.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Follow me, then.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Follow me, then.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original:
Thunder and lightning Enter Julius CAESAR in his nightgown
CAESAR
paragraphs.translated:
Thunder and lightning. CAESAR enters in his nightgown.
CAESAR

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
Nor heaven nor earth have been at peace tonight.
Thrice hath Calphurnia in her sleep cried out,
"Help, ho! They murder Caesar!" - Who's within?
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
Neither the sky nor the earth have been quiet tonight. Calphurnia cried out three times in her sleep, "Help, someone! They're murdering Caesar!" Who's there?

paragraphs.original:
Enter a SERVANT
SERVANT
paragraphs.translated:
A SERVANT enters.
SERVANT

paragraphs.original:
SERVANT
My lord.
paragraphs.translated:
SERVANT
My lord?

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
Go bid the priests do present sacrifice
And bring me their opinions of success.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
Go tell the priests to perform a sacrifice immediately, and bring me their interpretation of the results.

paragraphs.original:
SERVANT
I will, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
SERVANT
I will, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
Exit SERVANT
SERVANT
paragraphs.translated:
The SERVANT exits.
SERVANT

paragraphs.original:
Enter CALPHURNIA
CALPHURNIA
paragraphs.translated:
CALPHURNIA enters.
CALPHURNIA

paragraphs.original:
CALPHURNIA
What mean you, Caesar? Think you to walk forth?
You shall not stir out of your house today.
paragraphs.translated:
CALPHURNIA
What are you doing, Caesar? Are you planning to go out? You're not leaving the house today.

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
Caesar shall forth. The things that threatened me
Ne'er looked but on my back. When they shall see
The face of Caesar, they are vanishèd.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
I will go out. The things that threaten me have only seen my back. When they see the face of Caesar, they will vanish.

paragraphs.original:
CALPHURNIA
Caesar, I never stood on ceremonies,
Yet now they fright me. There is one within,
Besides the things that we have heard and seen,
Recounts most horrid sights seen by the watch.
A lioness hath whelpèd in the streets,
And graves have yawned and yielded up their dead.
paragraphs.translated:
CALPHURNIA
Caesar, I never believed in omens, but now they frighten me. A servant told me the night-watchmen saw horrid sights too, but different ones from what we heard and saw. A lioness gave birth in the streets, and graves cracked open and thrust out their dead.

paragraphs.original:
Fierce fiery warriors fought upon the clouds
In ranks and squadrons and right form of war,
Which drizzled blood upon the Capitol.
The noise of battle hurtled in the air.
Horses did neigh, and dying men did groan,
And ghosts did shriek and squeal about the streets.
O Caesar! These things are beyond all use,
And I do fear them.
paragraphs.translated: Fierce, fiery warriors fought in the clouds in the usual formations of war - ranks and squadrons - until the clouds drizzled blood onto the Capitol. The noise of battle filled the air, and horses neighed, and dying men groaned, and ghosts shrieked and squealed in the streets. Oh, Caesar! These things are beyond anything we've seen before, and I'm afraid.

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
What can be avoided
Whose end is purposed by the mighty gods?
Yet Caesar shall go forth, for these predictions
Are to the world in general as to Caesar.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
How can we avoid what the gods want to happen? But I will go out, for these bad omens apply to the world in general as much as they do to me.

paragraphs.original:
CALPHURNIA
When beggars die there are no comets seen.
The heavens themselves blaze forth the death of princes.
paragraphs.translated:
CALPHURNIA
When beggars die there are no comets in the sky. The heavens only announce the deaths of princes.

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
Cowards die many times before their deaths.
The valiant never taste of death but once.
Of all the wonders that I yet have heard,
It seems to me most strange that men should fear,
Seeing that death, a necessary end,
Will come when it will come.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
Cowards die many times before their deaths. The brave experience death only once. Of all the strange things I've ever heard, it seems most strange to me that men fear death, given that death, which can't be avoided, will come whenever it wants.

paragraphs.original:
Enter SERVANT
SERVANT
paragraphs.translated:
The SERVANT enters.
SERVANT

paragraphs.original: What say the augurers?
paragraphs.translated: What do the priests say?

paragraphs.original:
SERVANT
They would not have you to stir forth today.
Plucking the entrails of an offering forth,
They could not find a heart within the beast.
paragraphs.translated:
SERVANT
They don't want you to go out today. They pulled out the guts of the sacrificed animal and couldn't find its heart.

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
The gods do this in shame of cowardice.
Caesar should be a beast without a heart
If he should stay at home today for fear.
No, Caesar shall not. Danger knows full well
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
The gods do this to test my bravery. They're saying I'd be an animal without a heart if I stayed home today out of fear. So, I won't.

paragraphs.original:
That Caesar is more dangerous than he.
We are two lions littered in one day,
And I the elder and more terrible.
And Caesar shall go forth.
paragraphs.translated: Danger knows that Caesar is more dangerous than he is. We're two lions born on the same day in the same litter, and I'm the older and more terrible. I will go out.

paragraphs.original:
CALPHURNIA
Alas, my lord,
Your wisdom is consumed in confidence.
Do not go forth today. Call it my fear
That keeps you in the house, and not your own.
We'll send Mark Antony to the senate house,
And he shall say you are not well today.
(kneels) Let me, upon my knee, prevail in this.
(kneels)
paragraphs.translated:
CALPHURNIA
Alas, my lord, your confidence is getting the better of your wisdom. Don't go out today. Say that it's my fear that keeps you inside and not your own. We'll send Mark Antony to the senate house, and he'll say that you're sick today. (she kneels) Let me, on my knees, win you over to this plan.
(she kneels)

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
Mark Antony shall say I am not well,
And for thy humor I will stay at home.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
All right. Mark Antony will say I'm not well, and to please you I'll stay at home.

paragraphs.original:
CALPHURNIA rises
CALPHURNIA
paragraphs.translated:
CALPHURNIA gets up.
CALPHURNIA

paragraphs.original:
Enter DECIUS
DECIUS
paragraphs.translated:
DECIUS enters.
DECIUS

paragraphs.original: Here's Decius Brutus. He shall tell them so.
paragraphs.translated: Here's Decius Brutus. He'll tell them so.

paragraphs.original:
DECIUS
Caesar, all hail! Good morrow, worthy Caesar.
I come to fetch you to the senate house.
paragraphs.translated:
DECIUS
Hail, Caesar! Good morning, worthy Caesar. I've come to take you to the senate house.

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
And you are come in very happy time
To bear my greeting to the senators
And tell them that I will not come today.
"Cannot" is false, and that I dare not, falser.
I will not come today. Tell them so, Decius.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
And you've come at a good time, so you can convey my greetings to the senators and tell them I won't come today. It wouldn't be true to say that I can't come, and even less true to say that I don't dare come. I simply won't come today. Tell them so, Decius.
can't
dare
won't

paragraphs.original:
CALPHURNIA
Say he is sick.
paragraphs.translated:
CALPHURNIA
Say he's sick.

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
Shall Caesar send a lie?
Have I in conquest stretched mine arm so far
To be afraid to tell graybeards the truth?
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
Would I send a lie? Have I accomplished so much in battle, but now I'm afraid to tell some old men the truth?

paragraphs.original: Decius, go tell them Caesar will not come.
paragraphs.translated: Decius, go tell them that Caesar won't come.

paragraphs.original:
DECIUS
Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause,
Lest I be laughed at when I tell them so.
paragraphs.translated:
DECIUS
Most mighty Caesar, give me some reason, so I won't be laughed at when I tell them so.

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
The cause is in my will. I will not come.
That is enough to satisfy the senate.
But for your private satisfaction,
Because I love you, I will let you know.
Calphurnia here, my wife, stays me at home.
She dreamt tonight she saw my statue,
Which, like a fountain with an hundred spouts,
Did run pure blood. And many lusty Romans
Came smiling and did bathe their hands in it.
And these does she apply for warnings and portents
And evils imminent, and on her knee
Hath begged that I will stay at home today.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
The reason is that it's what I want. I'm not coming. That's enough for the senate. But for your private satisfaction, because I love you, I'll tell you. Calphurnia, my wife, is keeping me at home. Last night, she dreamed she saw a statue of me with a hundred holes in it, like a fountain with pure blood flowing from it, and many happy Romans came smiling and washed their hands in it. She takes these signs for warnings and predictions of terrible evils to come, and, on her knee, she begged me to stay home today.

paragraphs.original:
DECIUS
This dream is all amiss interpreted.
It was a vision fair and fortunate.
Your statue spouting blood in many pipes,
In which so many smiling Romans bathed,
Signifies that from you great Rome shall suck
Reviving blood, and that great men shall press
For tinctures, stains, relics, and cognizance.
This by Calphurnia's dream is signified.
paragraphs.translated:
DECIUS
This dream has been interpreted all wrong. It was a good and lucky vision. Your statue spouting blood through many holes, in which many smiling Romans bathed, means that you'll provide great Rome with sustaining blood, and that great men will strive to get some token of approval from your holy blood. This is what Calphurnia's dream means.

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
And this way have you well expounded it.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
You've offered an excellent interpretation.

paragraphs.original:
DECIUS
I have, when you have heard what I can say.
And know it now: the senate have concluded
To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar.
paragraphs.translated:
DECIUS
I will have when you hear the rest of what I have to say. The senate has decided to give mighty Caesar a crown today.

paragraphs.original:
If you shall send them word you will not come,
Their minds may change. Besides, it were a mock
Apt to be rendered for someone to say,
"Break up the senate till another time
When Caesar's wife shall meet with better dreams."
If Caesar hide himself, shall they not whisper,
"Lo, Caesar is afraid"?
Pardon me, Caesar. For my dear, dear love
To your proceeding bids me tell you this,
And reason to my love is liable.
paragraphs.translated: If you send them word that you won't come, they might change their minds. Besides, someone's likely to joke, "Adjourn the senate until some other time, when Caesar's wife has had better dreams." If you hide yourself, won't they whisper, "Caesar is afraid?" Pardon me, Caesar. My high hopes for your advancement force me to tell you this. My love gets the better of my manners.

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
How foolish do your fears seem now, Calphurnia!
I am ashamèd I did yield to them.
Give me my robe, for I will go.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
How foolish your fears seem now, Calphurnia! I'm ashamed that I yielded to them. Give me my robe, because I'm going.

paragraphs.original:
Enter BRUTUS, LIGARIUS, METELLUS, CASCA, TREBONIUS, CINNA, and PUBLIUS
BRUTUS
LIGARIUS
METELLUS
CASCA
TREBONIUS
CINNA
PUBLIUS
paragraphs.translated:
PUBLIUS, BRUTUS, LIGARIUS, METELLUS, CASCA, TREBONIUS, and CINNA enter.
PUBLIUS
BRUTUS
LIGARIUS
METELLUS
CASCA
TREBONIUS
CINNA

paragraphs.original: And look, where Publius is come to fetch me.
paragraphs.translated: And look, here's Publius, come to fetch me.

paragraphs.original:
PUBLIUS
Good morrow, Caesar.
paragraphs.translated:
PUBLIUS
Good morning, Caesar.

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
Welcome, Publius.
 - What, Brutus, are you stirred so early too?
 - Good morrow, Casca. - Caius Ligarius,
Caesar was ne'er so much your enemy
As that same ague which hath made you lean.
 - What is 't o'clock?
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
Welcome, Publius. What, Brutus? Are you up this early too? Good morning, Casca. Caius Ligarius, I was never your enemy so much as the sickness that's made you so thin. What time is it?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Caesar, 'tis strucken eight.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Caesar, the clock has struck eight.

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
I thank you for your pains and courtesy.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
I thank you all for your trouble and courtesy.

paragraphs.original:
Enter ANTONY
ANTONY
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY enters.
ANTONY

paragraphs.original:
See, Antony, that revels long a-nights,
Is notwithstanding up. - Good morrow, Antony.
paragraphs.translated: See! Even Antony, who stays up all night partying, is awake. Good morning, Antony.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
So to most noble Caesar.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
And to you, most noble Caesar.

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
Bid them prepare within.
I am to blame to be thus waited for.
 - Now, Cinna. - Now, Metellus. - What, Trebonius,
I have an hour's talk in store for you.
Remember that you call on me today.
Be near me, that I may remember you.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
Tell them to prepare the other room for guests. I'm to blame for making you wait for me. Now, Cinna. Now, Metellus. Trebonius! I have an hour-long matter to discuss with you. Remember to see me today. Stay near me so I'll remember.

paragraphs.original:
TREBONIUS
Caesar, I will. (aside) And so near will I be
(aside)
That your best friends shall wish I had been further.
paragraphs.translated:
TREBONIUS
Caesar, I will. (speaking quietly to himself) In fact, I'll be so near that your best friends will wish I'd been further away.
(speaking quietly to himself)

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
Good friends, go in and taste some wine with me.
And we, like friends, will straightway go together.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
Good friends, go in and have some wine with me. And we'll leave together, like friends.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
(aside) That every "like" is not the same, O Caesar,
(aside)
The heart of Brutus earns to think upon.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
(quietly to himself) That we are now only "like" friends - Oh Caesar - makes my heart ache.
(quietly to himself)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter ARTEMIDORUS, reading a letter
ARTEMIDORUS
paragraphs.translated:
ARTEMIDORUS enters, reading a letter.
ARTEMIDORUS

paragraphs.original:
ARTEMIDORUS
(reads aloud)
(reads aloud)
"Caesar, beware of Brutus. Take heed of Cassius. Come not near Casca. Have an eye to Cinna. Trust not Trebonius. Mark well Metellus Cimber. Decius Brutus loves thee not. Thou hast wronged Caius Ligarius. There is but one mind in all these men, and it is bent against Caesar. If thou beest not immortal, look about you. Security gives way to conspiracy. The mighty gods defend thee!
Thy lover,
Artemidorus"
Here will I stand till Caesar pass along,
And as a suitor will I give him this.
My heart laments that virtue cannot live
Out of the teeth of emulation.
If thou read this, O Caesar, thou mayst live.
If not, the Fates with traitors do contrive.
paragraphs.translated:
ARTEMIDORUS
(reading aloud from the letter)
(reading aloud from the letter)
"Caesar, beware of Brutus. Watch Cassius. Don't go near Casca. Keep an eye on Cinna. Don't trust Trebonius. Pay attention to Metellus Cimber. Decius Brutus doesn't love you. You've wronged Caius Ligarius. These men all have one intention, and it's directed against Caesar. If you aren't immortal, watch those around you. A sense of security opens the door to conspiracy. I pray that the mighty gods defend you!
Your friend,
Artemidorus."
I'll stand here until Caesar passes by, and I'll give him this as though it's a petition. My heart regrets that good men aren't safe from the bite of jealous rivals. If you read this, Caesar, you might live. If not, the Fates are on the side of the traitors.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
Enter PORTIA and LUCIUS
PORTIA
LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA and LUCIUS enter.
PORTIA
LUCIUS

paragraphs.original:
PORTIA
I prithee, boy, run to the senate house.
Stay not to answer me, but get thee gone.
Why dost thou stay?
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA
Boy, I beg you to run to the senate house. Don't stay to answer me - get going. Why are you still standing there?

paragraphs.original:
LUCIUS
To know my errand, madam.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS
To find out what you want me to do there, madam.

paragraphs.original:
PORTIA
I would have had thee there and here again
Ere I can tell thee what thou shouldst do there.
 - O constancy, be strong upon my side,
Set a huge mountain 'tween my heart and tongue!
I have a man's mind but a woman's might.
How hard it is for women to keep counsel!
 - Art thou here yet?
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA
I want you there and back again before I can even tell you what you should do there. (to herself, so that no one can hear her) Oh, let my determination keep me from speaking what is in my heart! I have a man's mind, but only a woman's strength. How hard it is for women to keep secrets! (to LUCIUS) Are you still here?
(to herself, so that no one can hear her)
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
LUCIUS
Madam, what should I do?
Run to the Capitol, and nothing else?
And so return to you, and nothing else?
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS
Madam, what should I do? Run to the Capitol and nothing else? And then return to you and nothing else?

paragraphs.original:
PORTIA
Yes, bring me word, boy, if thy lord look well,
For he went sickly forth. And take good note
What Caesar doth, what suitors press to him.
Hark, boy! What noise is that?
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA
Yes, return and tell me if your master looks well, because he was sick when he left. And pay attention to what Caesar does and which men are close to him. Listen, boy! What's that noise?

paragraphs.original:
LUCIUS
I hear none, madam.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS
I don't hear anything, madam.

paragraphs.original:
PORTIA
Prithee, listen well.
I heard a bustling rumor like a fray,
And the wind brings it from the Capitol.
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA
I beg you, listen well. I heard a noise like a scuffle. The wind brings it from the Capitol.

paragraphs.original:
LUCIUS
Sooth, madam, I hear nothing.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS
Truly, madam, I don't hear anything.

paragraphs.original:
Enter the SOOTHSAYER
SOOTHSAYER
paragraphs.translated:
The SOOTHSAYER enters.
SOOTHSAYER

paragraphs.original:
PORTIA
Come hither, fellow. Which way hast thou been?
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA
Come here, you. Where are you coming from?

paragraphs.original:
SOOTHSAYER
At mine own house, good lady.
paragraphs.translated:
SOOTHSAYER
My own house, good lady.

paragraphs.original:
PORTIA
What is 't o'clock?
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA
What time is it?

paragraphs.original:
SOOTHSAYER
About the ninth hour, lady.
paragraphs.translated:
SOOTHSAYER
Around nine o'clock, madam.

paragraphs.original:
PORTIA
Is Caesar yet gone to the Capitol?
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA
Has Caesar gone to the Capital yet?

paragraphs.original:
SOOTHSAYER
Madam, not yet. I go to take my stand
To see him pass on to the Capitol.
paragraphs.translated:
SOOTHSAYER
Madam, not yet. I'm going to stand so I can see him pass on the way to the Capitol.

paragraphs.original:
PORTIA
Thou hast some suit to Caesar, hast thou not?
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA
You have some plea for Caesar, don't you?

paragraphs.original:
SOOTHSAYER
That I have, lady. If it will please Caesar
To be so good to Caesar as to hear me,
I shall beseech him to befriend himself.
paragraphs.translated:
SOOTHSAYER
Yes, I do, lady. If it pleases Caesar to be so good to himself as to hear me, I'll try to get him to do what's good for him.

paragraphs.original:
PORTIA
Why, know'st thou any harm's intended towards him?
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA
Why, do you know of any harm intended toward him?

paragraphs.original:
SOOTHSAYER
None that I know will be; much that I fear may chance.
Good morrow to you. Here the street is narrow.
The throng that follows Caesar at the heels,
Of senators, of praetors, common suitors,
Will crowd a feeble man almost to death.
I'll get me to a place more void, and there
Speak to great Caesar as he comes along.
paragraphs.translated:
SOOTHSAYER
Nothing that I know for sure, but a lot that I'm afraid might happen. Good morning to you. The street is narrow here. The crowd that follows Caesar at his heels - senators, justices, common petitioners - will suffocate a feeble man almost to death. I'll move to a more open place and there speak to great Caesar as he walks past.

paragraphs.original:
Exit SOOTHSAYER
SOOTHSAYER
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
PORTIA
I must go in. (aside) Ay me, how weak a thing
(aside)
The heart of woman is! O Brutus,
The heavens speed thee in thine enterprise!
Sure, the boy heard me. (to LUCIUS) Brutus hath a suit
(to
)
That Caesar will not grant. - Oh, I grow faint. - 
Run, Lucius, and commend me to my lord.
Say I am merry. Come to me again,
And bring me word what he doth say to thee.
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA
I must go in. (speaking quietly to herself) Oh, a woman's heart is so weak! Oh Brutus, may the gods aid you in your endeavor! Surely, the boy heard me. (to LUCIUS) Brutus has a claim that Caesar won't grant. Oh, I feel faint. Run, Lucius, and speak well of me to my lord. Say that I'm happy. Then return to me and tell me what he says to you.
(speaking quietly to herself)
(to
)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt severally
paragraphs.translated: They exit in opposite directions.

paragraphs.original:
Flourish Enter CAESAR, BRUTUS, CASSIUS, CASCA, DECIUS, METELLUS, TREBONIUS, CINNA, ANTONY, LEPIDUS, PUBLIUS, and POPILLIUS LENA with a crowd of people, including ARTEMIDORUS and the SOOTHSAYER
CAESAR
BRUTUS
CASSIUS
CASCA
DECIUS
METELLUS
TREBONIUS
CINNA
ANTONY
LEPIDUS
PUBLIUS
POPILLIUS LENA
ARTEMIDORUS
SOOTHSAYER
paragraphs.translated:
A crowd of people enters, among them ARTEMIDORUS and the SOOTHSAYER. A trumpet plays. CAESAR, BRUTUS, CASSIUS, CASCA, DECIUS, METELLUS, TREBONIUS, CINNA, ANTONY, LEPIDUS, POPILLIUS, PUBLIUS, and others enter.
ARTEMIDORUS
SOOTHSAYER
CAESAR
BRUTUS
CASSIUS
CASCA
DECIUS
METELLUS
TREBONIUS
CINNA
ANTONY
LEPIDUS
POPILLIUS
PUBLIUS

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
(to the SOOTHSAYER) The ides of March are come.
(to the
)
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
(to the SOOTHSAYER) March 15th has come.
(to the
)

paragraphs.original:
SOOTHSAYER
Ay, Caesar, but not gone.
paragraphs.translated:
SOOTHSAYER
Yes, Caesar, but it's not gone yet.

paragraphs.original:
ARTEMIDORUS
(offering his letter) Hail, Caesar! Read this schedule.
(offering his letter)
paragraphs.translated:
ARTEMIDORUS
(offering his letter) Hail, Caesar! Read this schedule.
(offering his letter)

paragraphs.original:
DECIUS
(offering CAESAR another paper)
(offering
another paper)
Trebonius doth desire you to o'er-read,
At your best leisure, this his humble suit.
paragraphs.translated:
DECIUS
(offering CAESAR another paper) Trebonius wants you to look over his humble petition, at your leisure.
(offering
another paper)

paragraphs.original:
ARTEMIDORUS
O Caesar, read mine first, for mine's a suit
That touches Caesar nearer. Read it, great Caesar.
paragraphs.translated:
ARTEMIDORUS
Oh, Caesar, read mine first, for my petition affects you more directly. Read it, great Caesar.

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
What touches us ourself shall be last served.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
Whatever pertains to myself I will deal with last.

paragraphs.original:
ARTEMIDORUS
Delay not, Caesar. Read it instantly.
paragraphs.translated:
ARTEMIDORUS
Don't delay, Caesar. Read it instantly.

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
What, is the fellow mad?
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
What, is the man insane?

paragraphs.original:
PUBLIUS
(to ARTEMIDORUS)    Sirrah, give place.
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
PUBLIUS
(to ARTEMIDORUS) Stand aside, you.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
(to ARTEMIDORUS)
(to
)
What, urge you your petitions in the street?
Come to the Capitol.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
(to ARTEMIDORUS) What? Are you pressing your petition on the street? Go to the Capitol.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR's party moves aside to the senate house
CAESAR
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR goes up to the senate house, the rest following.
CAESAR

paragraphs.original:
POPILLIUS
(to CASSIUS) I wish your enterprise today may thrive.
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
POPILLIUS
(to CASSIUS) I hope your endeavor goes well today.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
What enterprise, Popillius?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
What endeavor, Popillius?

paragraphs.original:
POPILLIUS
Fare you well.
paragraphs.translated:
POPILLIUS
Good luck.

paragraphs.original:
(approaches CAESAR)
CAESAR
paragraphs.translated:
POPILLIUS approaches CAESAR.
POPILLIUS
CAESAR

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
(to CASSIUS) What said Popillius Lena?
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
(to CASSIUS) What did Popillius Lena say?
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
(aside to BRUTUS)
(aside to
)
He wished today our enterprise might thrive.
I fear our purpose is discoverèd.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
(speaking so that only BRUTUS can hear) He wished that our endeavor would go well today. I'm afraid we've been found out.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Look how he makes to Caesar. Mark him.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Look, he's approaching Caesar. Keep an eye on him.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Casca, be sudden, for we fear prevention
 - Brutus, what shall be done? If this be known,
Cassius or Caesar never shall turn back,
For I will slay myself.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Casca, be quick, because we're worried we might be stopped. Brutus, what will we do? If our secret's known, either Caesar or I will die, for I'll kill myself.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Cassius, be constant.
Popillius Lena speaks not of our purposes.
For, look, he smiles, and Caesar doth not change.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Cassius, stand firm. Popillius Lena wasn't talking about our plot - for, look, he's smiling, and Caesar's expression is the same.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Trebonius knows his time. For, look you, Brutus.
He draws Mark Antony out of the way.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Trebonius knows his cue. See, Brutus, he's pulling Mark Antony aside.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt TREBONIUS and ANTONY
TREBONIUS
ANTONY
paragraphs.translated:
TREBONIUS and ANTONY exit.
TREBONIUS
ANTONY

paragraphs.original:
DECIUS
Where is Metellus Cimber? Let him go
And presently prefer his suit to Caesar.
paragraphs.translated:
DECIUS
Where's Metellus Cimber? He should go up and offer his petition to Caesar now.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
He is addressed. Press near and second him.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
They're speaking to him. Go up there and second his petition.

paragraphs.original:
CINNA
Casca, you are the first that rears your hand.
paragraphs.translated:
CINNA
Casca, you'll be the first to raise your hand.

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
Are we all ready? What is now amiss
That Caesar and his senate must redress?
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
Are we all ready? What problem should I discuss with you first?

paragraphs.original:
METELLUS
(kneeling)
(kneeling)
Most high, most mighty, and most puissant Caesar,
Metellus Cimber throws before thy seat
An humble heart -
paragraphs.translated:
METELLUS
(kneeling) Most high, most mighty, and most powerful Caesar, Metellus Cimber kneels before you with a humble heart - 
(kneeling)

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
I must prevent thee, Cimber.
These couchings and these lowly courtesies
Might fire the blood of ordinary men
And turn preordinance and first decree
Into the law of children. Be not fond,
To think that Caesar bears such rebel blood
That will be thawed from the true quality
With that which melteth fools - I mean, sweet words,
Low-crookèd curtsies, and base spaniel fawning.
Thy brother by decree is banishèd.
If thou dost bend and pray and fawn for him,
I spurn thee like a cur out of my way.
Know, Caesar doth not wrong, nor without cause
Will he be satisfied.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
I have to stop you, Cimber. These kneelings and humble courtesies might excite ordinary men, flattering them into turning Roman law into children's games. But don't be so foolish as to think you can sway me from what's right by using the tactics that persuade fools - I mean this flattery, low bows, and puppy-like fawning. Your brother has been banished by decree. If you kneel and beg and flatter for him, I'll kick you out of my way like I would a dog. Know that I am not unjust, and I will not grant him a pardon without reason.
me

paragraphs.original:
METELLUS
Is there no voice more worthy than my own
To sound more sweetly in great Caesar's ear
For the repealing of my banished brother?
paragraphs.translated:
METELLUS
Is there no voice worthier than my own to appeal to Caesar to repeal the order that my brother be banished?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
(kneeling) I kiss thy hand, but not in flattery, Caesar,
(kneeling)
Desiring thee that Publius Cimber may
Have an immediate freedom of repeal.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
(kneeling) I kiss your hand, but not in flattery, Caesar. I ask you to repeal Publius Cimber's banishment immediately.
(kneeling)

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
What, Brutus?
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
What, even you, Brutus?

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
(kneeling)   Pardon, Caesar. Caesar, pardon.
(kneeling)
As low as to thy foot doth Cassius fall
To beg enfranchisement for Publius Cimber.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
(kneeling) Pardon him, Caesar, pardon him. I fall to your feet to beg you to restore Publius Cimber to citizenship.
(kneeling)

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
I could be well moved if I were as you.
If I could pray to move, prayers would move me.
But I am constant as the northern star,
Of whose true-fixed and resting quality
There is no fellow in the firmament.
The skies are painted with unnumbered sparks.
They are all fire and every one doth shine,
But there's but one in all doth hold his place.
So in the world. 'Tis furnished well with men,
And men are flesh and blood, and apprehensive,
Yet in the number I do know but one
That unassailable holds on his rank,
Unshaked of motion. And that I am he
Let me a little show it even in this:
That I was constant Cimber should be banished,
And constant do remain to keep him so.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
I could be convinced if I were like you. If I could beg others to change their minds, begging would convince me, too. But I'm as immovable as the northern star, whose stable and stationary quality has no equal in the sky. The sky shows countless stars. They're all made of fire, and each one shines. But only one among all of them remains in a fixed position. So it is on earth. The world is full of men, and men are flesh and blood, and they are capable of reason. Yet out of all of them, I know only one who is unassailable, who never moves from his position. To show you that that's me, let me prove it a little even in this case. I was firm in ordering that Cimber be banished, and I remain firm in that decision.

paragraphs.original:
CINNA
(kneeling) O Caesar - 
(kneeling)
paragraphs.translated:
CINNA
(kneeling) Oh, Caesar - 
(kneeling)

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
Hence! Wilt thou lift up Olympus?
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
Enough! Would you try to lift Mount Olympus?

paragraphs.original:
DECIUS
(kneeling) Great Caesar - 
(kneeling)
paragraphs.translated:
DECIUS
(kneeling) Great Caesar - 
(kneeling)

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
Doth not Brutus bootless kneel?
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
Haven't I resisted even Brutus, begging from his knees?

paragraphs.original:
CASCA
Speak, hands, for me!
paragraphs.translated:
CASCA
Hands, speak for me!

paragraphs.original:
CASCA and the other conspirators stab CAESAR, BRUTUS last
CASCA
CAESAR
BRUTUS
paragraphs.translated:
CASCA and the other conspirators stab CAESAR. BRUTUS stabs him last.
CASCA
CAESAR
BRUTUS

paragraphs.original:
CAESAR
Et tu, Bruté? - Then fall, Caesar.
Et tu, Bruté?
(dies)
(dies)
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR
And you too, Brutus? In that case, die, Caesar.
(he dies)
(he dies)

paragraphs.original:
CINNA
Liberty! Freedom! Tyranny is dead!
Run hence, proclaim, cry it about the streets.
paragraphs.translated:
CINNA
Liberty! Freedom! Tyranny is dead! Run and proclaim it in the streets.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Some to the common pulpits, and cry out,
"Liberty, freedom, and enfranchisement!"
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Some should go to the public platforms and cry out, "Liberty, freedom, and democracy!"

paragraphs.original: Confusion. Exeunt some plebians and senators
paragraphs.translated: Confusion. Some citizens and senators exit.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
People and senators, be not affrighted.
Fly not. Stand still. Ambition's debt is paid.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
People and senators, don't be afraid. Don't run away - stay where you are. Only Caesar had to die for his ambition.

paragraphs.original:
CASCA
Go to the pulpit, Brutus.
paragraphs.translated:
CASCA
Go to the platform, Brutus.

paragraphs.original:
DECIUS
And Cassius too.
paragraphs.translated:
DECIUS
And Cassius too.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Where's Publius?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Where's Publius?

paragraphs.original:
CINNA
Here, quite confounded with this mutiny.
paragraphs.translated:
CINNA
Here. He's completely stunned by this mutiny.

paragraphs.original:
METELLUS
Stand fast together, lest some friend of Caesar's
Should chance -
paragraphs.translated:
METELLUS
Stand close together, in case someone loyal to Caesar tries to -

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Talk not of standing. - Publius, good cheer.
There is no harm intended to your person,
Nor to no Roman else. So tell them, Publius.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Don't talk about standing together. - Publius, cheer up. We don't intend any harm to you, nor to anyone else. Tell them this, Publius.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
And leave us, Publius, lest that the people,
Rushing on us, should do your age some mischief.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
And leave us, Publius, in case the people storming us should harm you.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Do so. And let no man abide this deed
But we the doers.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Do so. And let no one suffer for this deed except us, the perpetrators.

paragraphs.original:
Exit PUBLIUS
PUBLIUS
paragraphs.translated:
PUBLIUS exits.
PUBLIUS

paragraphs.original:
Enter TREBONIUS
TREBONIUS
paragraphs.translated:
TREBONIUS enters.
TREBONIUS

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Where is Antony?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Where's Antony?

paragraphs.original:
TREBONIUS
Fled to his house amazed.
Men, wives, and children stare, cry out, and run
As it were doomsday.
paragraphs.translated:
TREBONIUS
He ran to his house, stunned. Men, wives, and children stare, cry out, and run in the streets as though it were doomsday.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Fates, we will know your pleasures.
That we shall die, we know. 'Tis but the time,
And drawing days out, that men stand upon.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
We'll soon find out what fate has in store for us. All we know is that we'll die sometime, which is all anyone ever knows, though we try to draw out our days for as long as possible.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Why, he that cuts off twenty years of life
Cuts off so many years of fearing death.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Why, the man who shortens his life by twenty years cuts off twenty years of worrying about death.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Grant that, and then is death a benefit.
So are we Caesar's friends, that have abridged
His time of fearing death. Stoop, Romans, stoop,
And let us bathe our hands in Caesar's blood
Up to the elbows, and besmear our swords.
Then walk we forth, even to the marketplace,
And waving our red weapons o'er our heads
Let's all cry, "Peace, freedom, and liberty!"
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
So, then, death is a gift, and we are Caesar's friends, for we've done him a service by shortening his time spent fearing death. Kneel, Romans, kneel, and let's wash our hands, up to the elbows, in Caesar's blood and smear it on our swords. Then we'll go out, even to the marketplace, and, waving our bloody swords over our heads, let's cry, "Peace, freedom, and liberty!"

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Stoop, then, and wash.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Kneel then, and wash.

paragraphs.original:
The conspirators smear their hands and swords with CAESAR's blood
CAESAR
paragraphs.translated:
The conspirators smear their hands and swords with CAESAR's blood.
CAESAR

paragraphs.original:
How many ages hence
Shall this our lofty scene be acted over
In states unborn and accents yet unknown!
paragraphs.translated: How many years from now will this heroic scene be reenacted in countries that don't even exist yet and in languages not yet known!

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
How many times shall Caesar bleed in sport,
That now on Pompey's basis lies along
No worthier than the dust!
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
How many times will Caesar bleed again in show, though he now lies at the base of Pompey's statue, as worthless as dust!

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
So oft as that shall be,
So often shall the knot of us be called
"The men that gave their country liberty."
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
As often as it's replayed, our group will be hailed as the men who gave their country liberty.

paragraphs.original:
DECIUS
What, shall we forth?
paragraphs.translated:
DECIUS
Well, should we go out?

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Ay, every man away.
Brutus shall lead, and we will grace his heels
With the most boldest and best hearts of Rome.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Yes, every man forward. Brutus will lead, and we'll follow him with the boldest and best hearts of Rome.

paragraphs.original:
Enter ANTONY'S SERVANT
ANTONY'S SERVANT
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY'S SERVANT enters.
ANTONY'S SERVANT

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Soft! Who comes here? A friend of Antony's.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Wait a minute. Who's that coming? It's a friend of Antony's.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY'S SERVANT
(kneeling) Thus, Brutus, did my master bid me kneel.
(kneeling)
(falls prostrate) Thus did Mark Antony bid me fall down,
(falls prostrate)
And, being prostrate, thus he bade me say:
Brutus is noble, wise, valiant, and honest.
Caesar was mighty, bold, royal, and loving.
Say I love Brutus, and I honor him.
Say I feared Caesar, honored him, and loved him.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY'S SERVANT
(kneeling) Brutus, my master ordered me to kneel like this. (he kneels, head bowed low) He ordered me to kneel low, and, from the ground, like this, he ordered me to say: "Brutus is noble, wise, brave, and honest. Caesar was mighty, bold, royal, and loving. Antony loves Brutus and honors him. Antony feared Caesar, honored him, and loved him.
(kneeling)
(he kneels, head bowed low)

paragraphs.original:
If Brutus will vouchsafe that Antony
May safely come to him and be resolved
How Caesar hath deserved to lie in death,
Mark Antony shall not love Caesar dead
So well as Brutus living, but will follow
The fortunes and affairs of noble Brutus
Thorough the hazards of this untrod state
With all true faith. So says my master Antony.
paragraphs.translated: If Brutus will swear that Antony may come to him safely and be convinced that Caesar deserved to be killed, Mark Antony will love dead Caesar not nearly as much as living Brutus, and with true faith he'll follow the destiny and affairs of noble Brutus through the difficulties of this unprecedented state of affairs." That's what my master, Antony, says.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Thy master is a wise and valiant Roman.
I never thought him worse.
Tell him, so please him come unto this place,
He shall be satisfied and, by my honor,
Depart untouched.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Your master is a wise and honorable Roman. I never thought any less of him. Tell him, if he comes here, I'll explain everything to him and, on my word, he'll leave unharmed.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY'S SERVANT
(rising)    I'll fetch him presently.
(rising)
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY'S SERVANT
(getting up) I'll get him now.
(getting up)

paragraphs.original:
Exit ANTONY'S SERVANT
ANTONY'S SERVANT
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY'S SERVANT exits.
ANTONY'S SERVANT

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
I know that we shall have him well to friend.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
I know that he'll be on our side.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
I wish we may. But yet have I a mind
That fears him much, and my misgiving still
Falls shrewdly to the purpose.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
I hope we can count on him, but I still fear him, and my hunches are usually accurate.

paragraphs.original:
Enter ANTONY
ANTONY
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY enters.
ANTONY

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
But here comes Antony. - Welcome, Mark Antony.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
But here comes Antony. - Welcome, Mark Antony.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
O mighty Caesar! Dost thou lie so low?
Are all thy conquests, glories, triumphs, spoils,
Shrunk to this little measure? Fare thee well.
 - I know not, gentlemen, what you intend,
Who else must be let blood, who else is rank.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Oh, mighty Caesar! Do you lie so low? Have all your conquests, glories, triumphs, achievements, come to so little? Farewell. Gentlemen, I don't know what you intend to do, who else you intend to kill, who else you consider corrupt.

paragraphs.original:
If I myself, there is no hour so fit
As Caesar's death's hour, nor no instrument
Of half that worth as those your swords, made rich
With the most noble blood of all this world.
I do beseech ye, if you bear me hard,
Now, whilst your purpled hands do reek and smoke,
Fulfill your pleasure. Live a thousand years,
I shall not find myself so apt to die.
No place will please me so, no mean of death,
As here by Caesar, and by you cut off,
The choice and master spirits of this age.
paragraphs.translated: If it's me, there's no time as good as this hour of Caesar's death, and no weapon better than your swords, covered with the noblest blood in the world. I ask you, if you have a grudge against me, to kill me now, while your stained hands still reek of blood. I could live a thousand years and I wouldn't be as ready to die as I am now. There's no place I'd rather die than here by Caesar, and no manner of death would please me more than being stabbed by you, the masters of this new era.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
O Antony, beg not your death of us.
Though now we must appear bloody and cruel - 
As by our hands and this our present act
You see we do - yet see you but our hands
And this the bleeding business they have done.
Our hearts you see not. They are pitiful.
And pity to the general wrong of Rome - 
As fire drives out fire, so pity pity - 
Hath done this deed on Caesar. For your part,
To you our swords have leaden points, Mark Antony.
Our arms in strength of malice and our hearts
Of brothers' temper do receive you in
With all kind love, good thoughts, and reverence.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Oh, Antony, don't beg us to kill you. Though we seem bloody and cruel right now, with our bloody hands and this deed we've done, you've only seen our hands and their bloody business; you haven't looked into our hearts. They are full of pity for Caesar. But a stronger pity, for the wrongs committed against Rome, drove out our pity for Caesar, as fire drives out fire, and so we killed him. For you, our swords have blunt edges, too dull to harm you, Mark Antony. Our arms, which can be strong and cruel, and our hearts, filled with brotherly love, embrace you with kind love, good thoughts, and reverence.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Your voice shall be as strong as any man's
In the disposing of new dignities.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Your vote will be as strong as anyone's in the reordering of the government.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Only be patient till we have appeased
The multitude, beside themselves with fear,
And then we will deliver you the cause,
Why I, that did love Caesar when I struck him,
Have thus proceeded.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
But just be patient until we've calmed the masses, who are beside themselves with fear. Then we'll explain to you why I, who loved Caesar even while I stabbed him, have taken this course of action.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
I doubt not of your wisdom.
Let each man render me his bloody hand.
(shakes hands with the conspirators)
(shakes hands with the conspirators)
First, Marcus Brutus, will I shake with you.
 - Next, Caius Cassius, do I take your hand.
 - Now, Decius Brutus, yours. - Now yours, Metellus.
 - Yours, Cinna. - And, my valiant Casca, yours.
 - Though last, not last in love, yours, good Trebonius.
 - Gentlemen all, alas, what shall I say?
My credit now stands on such slippery ground
That one of two bad ways you must conceit me,
Either a coward or a flatterer
 - That I did love thee, Caesar, O, 'tis true.
If then thy spirit look upon us now,
Shall it not grieve thee dearer than thy death
To see thy Antony making his peace,
Shaking the bloody fingers of thy foes - 
Most noble! - in the presence of thy corse?
Had I as many eyes as thou hast wounds,
Weeping as fast as they stream forth thy blood,
It would become me better than to close
In terms of friendship with thine enemies.
Pardon me, Julius! Here wast thou bayed, brave hart;
Here didst thou fall; and here thy hunters stand,
Signed in thy spoil, and crimsoned in thy lethe.
O world, thou wast the forest to this hart,
And this indeed, O world, the heart of thee.
How like a deer, strucken by many princes,
Dost thou here lie!
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
I don't doubt your wisdom. Each of you, give me your bloody hand. (he shakes hands with the conspirators) First, Marcus Brutus, I shake your hand. Next, Caius Cassius, I take your hand. Now, Decius Brutus, yours. Now yours, Metellus. Yours, Cinna. And yours, my brave Casca. Last but not least, yours, good Trebonius. You are all gentlemen - alas, what can I say? Now that I've shaken your hands, you'll take me for either a coward or a flatterer - in either case, my credibility stands on slippery ground. It's true that I loved you, Caesar - nothing could be truer. If your spirit is looking down upon us now, it must hurt you more than even your death to see your Antony making peace - shaking the bloody hands of your enemies - in front of your corpse. If I had as many eyes as you have wounds, and they wept as fast as your wounds stream blood - even that would be more becoming than joining your enemies in friendship. Forgive me, Julius! On this very spot you were hunted down, like a brave deer. And here you fell, where your hunters are now standing. The spot is marked by your death and stained by your blood. Oh world, you were the forest to this deer, and this deer, oh world, was your dear. Now you lie here, stabbed by many princes!
(he shakes hands with the conspirators)

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Mark Antony -
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Mark Antony -

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Pardon me, Caius Cassius.
The enemies of Caesar shall say this;
Then, in a friend, it is cold modesty.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Pardon me, Caius Cassius. Even Caesar's enemies would say the same. From a friend, it's a cool assessment - no more than that.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
I blame you not for praising Caesar so.
But what compact mean you to have with us?
Will you be pricked in number of our friends?
Or shall we on, and not depend on you?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
I don't blame you for praising Caesar like this, but what agreement do you intend to reach with us? Will you be counted as our friend, or should we proceed without depending on you?

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Therefore I took your hands, but was indeed
Swayed from the point by looking down on Caesar.
Friends am I with you all and love you all
Upon this hope: that you shall give me reasons
Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
I took your hands in friendship, but, indeed, I was distracted when I looked down at Caesar. I am friends with you all and love you all, on one condition - that you prove to me that Caesar was dangerous.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Or else were this a savage spectacle!
Our reasons are so full of good regard
That were you, Antony, the son of Caesar,
You should be satisfied.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Without that proof, this would've been a savage action! Our reasons are so well considered that even if you, Antony, were Caesar's son, you would be satisfied with them.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
That's all I seek.
And am moreover suitor that I may
Produce his body to the marketplace,
And in the pulpit, as becomes a friend,
Speak in the order of his funeral.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
That's all I ask - and that you let me carry his body to the marketplace and, as a friend ought to do, stand on the platform and give a proper funeral oration.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
You shall, Mark Antony.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
You may, Mark Antony.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Brutus, a word with you.
(aside to BRUTUS) You know not what you do.
(aside to
)
Do not consent
That Antony speak in his funeral.
Know you how much the people may be moved
By that which he will utter?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Brutus, may I have a word with you? (speaking so that only BRUTUS can hear) You don't know what you're doing. Don't let Antony speak at his funeral. Don't you know how much the people could be affected by what he says?
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
(aside to CASSIUS)    By your pardon.
(aside to
)
I will myself into the pulpit first,
And show the reason of our Caesar's death.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
(speaking so that only CASSIUS can hear) With your permission, I'll stand on the platform first and explain the reason for Caesar's death.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
What Antony shall speak, I will protest,
He speaks by leave and by permission,
And that we are contented Caesar shall
Have all true rites and lawful ceremonies.
It shall advantage more than do us wrong.
paragraphs.translated: What Antony says, I'll announce, he says only by our permission and by our conviction that Caesar should be honored with all the usual and lawful ceremonies. It'll help us more than hurt us.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
(aside to BRUTUS) I know not what may fall. I like it not.
(aside to
)
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
(speaking so that only BRUTUS can hear) I'm worried about the outcome of his speech. I don't like this plan.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Mark Antony, here, take you Caesar's body.
You shall not in your funeral speech blame us,
But speak all good you can devise of Caesar,
And say you do 't by our permission.
Else shall you not have any hand at all
About his funeral. And you shall speak
In the same pulpit whereto I am going,
After my speech is ended.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Mark Antony, take Caesar's body. You will not blame us in your funeral speech, but will say all the good you want to about Caesar and that you do it by our permission. Otherwise, you'll have no role at all in his funeral. And you'll speak on the same platform as I do, after I'm done.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Be it so.
I do desire no more.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
So be it. I don't want anything more.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Prepare the body then, and follow us.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Prepare the body, then, and follow us.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt. Manet ANTONY
ANTONY
paragraphs.translated:
Everyone except ANTONY exits.
ANTONY

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
O, pardon me, thou bleeding piece of earth,
That I am meek and gentle with these butchers!
Thou art the ruins of the noblest man
That ever livèd in the tide of times.
Woe to the hand that shed this costly blood!
Over thy wounds now do I prophesy - 
Which, like dumb mouths, do ope their ruby lips
To beg the voice and utterance of my tongue - 
A curse shall light upon the limbs of men.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Oh, pardon me, you bleeding corpse, for speaking politely and acting mildly with these butchers! You are what's left of the noblest man that ever lived. Pity the hand that shed this valuable blood. Over your wounds - which, like speechless mouths, open their red lips, as though to beg me to speak - I predict that a curse will fall upon the bodies of men.

paragraphs.original:
Domestic fury and fierce civil strife
Shall cumber all the parts of Italy.
Blood and destruction shall be so in use,
And dreadful objects so familiar,
That mothers shall but smile when they behold
Their infants quartered with the hands of war,
All pity choked with custom of fell deeds,
And Caesar's spirit, ranging for revenge,
With Ate by his side come hot from hell,
Shall in these confines with a monarch's voice
Cry "Havoc!" and let slip the dogs of war,
That this foul deed shall smell above the earth
With carrion men, groaning for burial.
paragraphs.translated:
Fierce civil war will paralyze all of Italy. Blood and destruction will be so common and familiar that mothers will merely smile when their infants are cut to pieces by the hands of war. People's capacity for sympathy will grow tired and weak from the sheer quantity of cruel deeds. And Caesar's ghost, searching for revenge with the goddess
Ate by his side, just up from Hell, will cry in the voice of a king, "Havoc!" and unleash the dogs of war. This foul deed will stink up to the sky with men's corpses, which will beg to be buried.
Ate

paragraphs.original:
Enter OCTAVIUS' SERVANT
OCTAVIUS' SERVANT
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT enters.
OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT

paragraphs.original: You serve Octavius Caesar, do you not?
paragraphs.translated: You serve Octavius Caesar, right?

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS' SERVANT
I do, Mark Antony.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT
I do, Mark Antony.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Caesar did write for him to come to Rome.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Caesar wrote for him to come to Rome.

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS' SERVANT
He did receive his letters and is coming.
And bid me say to you by word of mouth - 
(sees CAESAR's body) O Caesar! - 
(sees
's body)
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT
He received Caesar's letters, and he is coming. He told me to say to you - (seeing CAESAR's body) Oh, Caesar! - 
(seeing
s
body)

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Thy heart is big. Get thee apart and weep.
Passion, I see, is catching, for mine eyes,
Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine,
Began to water. Is thy master coming?
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Your heart is big; go ahead and weep. Grief seems to be contagious, for my eyes, seeing the tears in yours, began to fill. Is your master coming?

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS' SERVANT
He lies tonight within seven leagues of Rome.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT
He rests tonight within twenty-one miles of Rome.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Post back with speed, and tell him what hath chanced.
Here is a mourning Rome, a dangerous Rome,
No Rome of safety for Octavius yet.
Hie hence, and tell him so. - Yet, stay awhile.
Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corse
Into the marketplace. There shall I try,
In my oration, how the people take
The cruèl issue of these bloody men.
According to the which, thou shalt discourse
To young Octavius of the state of things.
Lend me your hand.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Report back to him fast and tell him what has happened. This is now a Rome in mourning, a dangerous Rome. It's not safe enough for Octavius yet. Hurry away and tell him so. No, wait, stay a minute. Don't go back until I've carried the corpse into the marketplace. There I'll use my speech to test what the people think of these bloody men's cruel action. You'll report back to young Octavius how they respond. Help me here.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt with CAESAR's body
CAESAR
paragraphs.translated:
They exit with CAESAR's body.
CAESAR

paragraphs.original:
Enter BRUTUS and CASSIUS with the PLEBEIANS
BRUTUS
CASSIUS
PLEBEIANS
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS and CASSIUS enter with a throng of
PLEBEIANS .
BRUTUS
CASSIUS
PLEBEIANS
PLEBEIANS

paragraphs.original:
PLEBEIANS
We will be satisfied! Let us be satisfied!
paragraphs.translated:
PLEBEIANS
We want answers. Give us answers.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Then follow me and give me audience, friends.
 - Cassius, go you into the other street
And part the numbers.
 - Those that will hear me speak, let 'em stay here.
Those that will follow Cassius, go with him,
And public reasons shall be renderèd
Of Caesar's death.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Then follow me and listen to my speech, friends. Cassius, go to the next street and divide the crowd. Let those who will hear me speak stay. Lead those away who will follow you, and we'll explain publicly the reasons for Caesar's death.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
I will hear Brutus speak.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
I'll listen to Brutus.

paragraphs.original:
ANOTHER PLEBEIAN
I will hear Cassius and compare their reasons
When severally we hear them renderèd.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
I'll listen to Cassius, and we will compare their reasons.

paragraphs.original:
Exit CASSIUS with some of the PLEBEIANS BRUTUS goes into the pulpit
CASSIUS
PLEBEIANS
BRUTUS
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS exits with some of the PLEBEIANS. BRUTUS gets up on the platform.
CASSIUS
PLEBEIANS
BRUTUS

paragraphs.original:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
The noble Brutus is ascended. Silence!
paragraphs.translated:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Quiet! Noble Brutus has mounted the platform.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Be patient till the last. Romans, countrymen, and lovers! Hear me for my cause, and be silent that you may hear. Believe me for mine honor, and have respect to mine honor that you may believe. Censure me in your wisdom, and awake your senses that you may the better judge. If there be any in this assembly, any dear friend of Caesar's, to him I say that Brutus' love to Caesar was no less than his. If then that friend demand why Brutus rose against Caesar, this is my answer: not that I loved Caesar less, but that I loved Rome more.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Be patient until I finish. Romans, countrymen, and friends! Listen to my reasons and be silent so you can hear. Believe me on my honor and keep my honor in mind, so you may believe me. Be wise when you criticize me and keep your minds alert so you can judge me fairly. If there's anyone in this assembly, any dear friend of Caesar's, I say to him that my love for Caesar was no less than his. If, then, that friend demands to know why I rose up against Caesar, this is my answer: it's not that I loved Caesar less, but that I loved Rome more.

paragraphs.original: Had you rather Caesar were living and die all slaves, than that Caesar were dead, to live all free men? As Caesar loved me, I weep for him. As he was fortunate, I rejoice at it. As he was valiant, I honor him. But, as he was ambitious, I slew him. There is tears for his love, joy for his fortune, honor for his valor, and death for his ambition. Who is here so base that would be a bondman? If any, speak - for him have I offended. Who is here so rude that would not be a Roman? If any, speak - for him have I offended. Who is here so vile that will not love his country? If any, speak - for him have I offended. I pause for a reply.
paragraphs.translated: Would you rather that Caesar were living and we would all go to our graves as slaves, or that Caesar were dead and we all lived as free men? I weep for Caesar in that he was good to me. I rejoice in his good fortune. I honor him for being brave. But his ambition - for that, I killed him. There are tears for his love, joy for his fortune, honor for his bravery, and death for his ambition. Who here is so low that he wants to be a slave? If there are any, speak, for it is he whom I've offended. Who here is so barbarous that he doesn't want to be a Roman? If there are any, speak, for it is he whom I've offended. Who here is so vile that he doesn't love his country? If there are any, speak, for it is he whom I have offended. I will pause for a reply.

paragraphs.original:
ALL
None, Brutus, none.
paragraphs.translated:
ALL
No one, Brutus, no one.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Then none have I offended. I have done no more to Caesar than you shall do to Brutus. The question of his death is enrolled in the Capitol. His glory not extenuated wherein he was worthy, nor his offenses enforced for which he suffered death.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Then I have offended no one. I've done no more to Caesar than you will do to me. The reasons for his death are recorded in the Capitol. His glory has not been diminished where he earned it, nor have those offenses for which he was killed been exaggerated.

paragraphs.original:
Enter Mark ANTONY with CAESAR's body
ANTONY
CAESAR
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY enters with CAESAR's body.
ANTONY
CAESAR

paragraphs.original: Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony, who, though he had no hand in his death, shall receive the benefit of his dying - a place in the commonwealth - as which of you shall not? With this I depart: that, as I slew my best lover for the good of Rome, I have the same dagger for myself when it shall please my country to need my death.
paragraphs.translated: Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony, who, though he had no part in the killing, will benefit from his death - receiving a share in the commonwealth, as you all will. With these words I leave. Just as I killed my best friend for the good of Rome, so will I kill myself when my country requires my death.

paragraphs.original:
ALL
Live, Brutus! Live, live!
paragraphs.translated:
ALL
Live, Brutus! Live, live!

paragraphs.original:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Bring him with triumph home unto his house!
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Let's carry him in triumph to his house!

paragraphs.original:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Give him a statue with his ancestors!
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Let's build a statue of him, near those of his ancestors!

paragraphs.original:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Let him be Caesar!
paragraphs.translated:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Let him become Caesar!

paragraphs.original:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
Caesar's better parts
Shall be crowned in Brutus!
paragraphs.translated:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
Caesar's better qualities exist in Brutus, and we will crown him.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
We'll bring him to his house with shouts and clamors.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
We'll bring him to his house with shouts and celebration!

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
My countrymen -
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
My countrymen -

paragraphs.original:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Peace, silence! Brutus speaks.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Silence! Brutus speaks.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Peace, ho!
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Quiet there!

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Good countrymen, let me depart alone.
And, for my sake, stay here with Antony.
Do grace to Caesar's corpse, and grace his speech
Tending to Caesar's glories, which Mark Antony
By our permission is allowed to make.
I do entreat you, not a man depart,
Save I alone, till Antony have spoke.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Good countrymen, let me leave alone. I want you to stay here with Antony to pay respects to Caesar's corpse and listen to Antony's speech about Caesar's glories, which he gives with our permission. I ask that none of you leave, except myself, until Antony has finished.

paragraphs.original:
Exit BRUTUS
BRUTUS
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS exits.
BRUTUS

paragraphs.original:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Stay, ho! And let us hear Mark Antony.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Let's stay and hear Mark Antony.

paragraphs.original:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Let him go up into the public chair.
We'll hear him. - Noble Antony, go up.
paragraphs.translated:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
