Let him mount the pulpit. We'll listen to him. Noble Antony, mount the podium.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
For Brutus' sake, I am beholding to you.
(ascends the pulpit)
(ascends the pulpit)
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
For Brutus's sake, I am indebted to you.
(he steps up into the pulpit)
(he steps up into the pulpit)

paragraphs.original:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
What does he say of Brutus?
paragraphs.translated:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
What does he say about Brutus?

paragraphs.original:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
He says for Brutus' sake
He finds himself beholding to us all.
paragraphs.translated:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
He says that for Brutus's sake he finds himself indebted to us all.

paragraphs.original:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
'Twere best he speak no harm of Brutus here.
paragraphs.translated:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
He'd better not speak badly of Brutus here.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
This Caesar was a tyrant.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Caesar was a tyrant.

paragraphs.original:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Nay, that's certain.
We are blest that Rome is rid of him.
paragraphs.translated:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
That's for sure. We're lucky that Rome is rid of him.

paragraphs.original:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
Peace! Let us hear what Antony can say.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Quiet! Let's hear what Antony has to say.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
You gentle Romans -
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
You gentle Romans -

paragraphs.original:
ALL
Peace, ho! Let us hear him.
paragraphs.translated:
ALL
Quiet there! Let us hear him.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears.
I come to bury Caesar, not to praise him.
The evil that men do lives after them;
The good is oft interrèd with their bones.
So let it be with Caesar. The noble Brutus
Hath told you Caesar was ambitious.
If it were so, it was a grievous fault,
And grievously hath Caesar answered it.
Here, under leave of Brutus and the rest - 
For Brutus is an honorable man;
So are they all, all honorable men - 
Come I to speak in Caesar's funeral.
He was my friend, faithful and just to me.
But Brutus says he was ambitious,
And Brutus is an honorable man.
He hath brought many captives home to Rome
Whose ransoms did the general coffers fill.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Friends, Romans, countrymen, give me your attention. I have come here to bury Caesar, not to praise him. The evil that men do is remembered after their deaths, but the good is often buried with them. It might as well be the same with Caesar. The noble Brutus told you that Caesar was ambitious. If that's true, it's a serious fault, and Caesar has paid seriously for it. With the permission of Brutus and the others - for Brutus is an honorable man; they are all honorable men - I have come here to speak at Caesar's funeral. He was my friend, he was faithful and just to me. But Brutus says he was ambitious, and Brutus is an honorable man. He brought many captives home to Rome whose ransoms brought wealth to the city.

paragraphs.original:
Did this in Caesar seem ambitious?
When that the poor have cried, Caesar hath wept.
Ambition should be made of sterner stuff.
Yet Brutus says he was ambitious,
And Brutus is an honorable man.
You all did see that on the Lupercal
I thrice presented him a kingly crown,
Which he did thrice refuse. Was this ambition?
Yet Brutus says he was ambitious,
And, sure, he is an honorable man.
I speak not to disprove what Brutus spoke,
But here I am to speak what I do know.
You all did love him once, not without cause.
What cause withholds you then to mourn for him?
O judgment! Thou art fled to brutish beasts,
And men have lost their reason. Bear with me.
My heart is in the coffin there with Caesar,
And I must pause till it come back to me. (weeps)
(weeps)
paragraphs.translated:
Is this the work of an ambitious man? When the poor cried, Caesar cried too. Ambition shouldn't be so soft. Yet Brutus says he was ambitious, and Brutus is an honorable man. You all saw that on the Lupercal feast day I offered him a king's crown three times, and he refused it three times. Was this ambition? Yet Brutus says he was ambitious. And, no question, Brutus is an honorable man. I am not here to disprove what Brutus has said, but to say what I know. You all loved him once, and not without reason. Then what reason holds you back from mourning him now? Men have become brutish beasts and lost their reason! Bear with me. My heart is in the coffin there with Caesar, and I must pause until it returns to me. (he weeps)
I
(he weeps)

paragraphs.original:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Methinks there is much reason in his sayings.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
I think there's a lot of sense in what he says.

paragraphs.original:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
If thou consider rightly of the matter,
Caesar has had great wrong.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
If you think about it correctly, Caesar has suffered a great wrong.

paragraphs.original:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Has he, masters?
I fear there will a worse come in his place.
paragraphs.translated:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Has he, sirs? I'm worried there will be someone worse to replace him.

paragraphs.original:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
Marked ye his words? He would not take the crown.
Therefore 'tis certain he was not ambitious.
paragraphs.translated:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
Did you hear Antony? Caesar wouldn't take the crown. Therefore it's certain that he wasn't ambitious.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
If it be found so, some will dear abide it.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
If it turns out he wasn't, certain people are going to get it.

paragraphs.original:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Poor soul! His eyes are red as fire with weeping.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Poor man! Antony's eyes are fiery red from crying.

paragraphs.original:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
There's not a nobler man in Rome than Antony.
paragraphs.translated:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
There isn't a nobler man than Antony in all of Rome.

paragraphs.original:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
Now mark him. He begins again to speak.
paragraphs.translated:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
Now listen, he's going to speak again.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
But yesterday the word of Caesar might
Have stood against the world. Now lies he there,
And none so poor to do him reverence.
O masters, if I were disposed to stir
Your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage,
I should do Brutus wrong, and Cassius wrong - 
Who, you all know, are honorable men.
I will not do them wrong. I rather choose
To wrong the dead, to wrong myself and you,
Than I will wrong such honorable men.
But here's a parchment with the seal of Caesar.
I found it in his closet. 'Tis his will.
Let but the commons hear this testament - 
Which, pardon me, I do not mean to read - 
And they would go and kiss dead Caesar's wounds
And dip their napkins in his sacred blood,
Yea, beg a hair of him for memory,
And, dying, mention it within their wills,
Bequeathing it as a rich legacy
Unto their issue.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Only yesterday the word of Caesar might have stood against the world. Now he lies there worth nothing, and no one is so humble as to show him respect. Oh, sirs, if I stirred your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage, I would offend Brutus and Cassius, who, you all know, are honorable men. I will not do them wrong. I would rather wrong the dead, and wrong myself and you, than wrong such honorable men. But here's a paper with Caesar's seal on it. I found it in his room - it's his will. If you could only hear this testament - which, excuse me, I don't intend to read aloud - you would kiss dead Caesar's wounds and dip your handkerchiefs in his sacred blood, and beg for a lock of hair to remember him by. And when you died, you would mention the handkerchief or the hair in your will, bequeathing it to your heirs like a rich legacy.

paragraphs.original:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
We'll hear the will. Read it, Mark Antony!
paragraphs.translated:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
We want to hear the will. Read it, Mark Antony.

paragraphs.original:
ALL
The will, the will! We will hear Caesar's will.
paragraphs.translated:
ALL
The will, the will! We want to hear Caesar's will.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Have patience, gentle friends. I must not read it.
It is not meet you know how Caesar loved you.
You are not wood, you are not stones, but men.
And, being men, bearing the will of Caesar,
It will inflame you, it will make you mad.
'Tis good you know not that you are his heirs.
For, if you should - Oh, what would come of it!
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Be patient, gentle friends, I must not read it. It isn't proper for you to know how much Caesar loved you. You aren't wood, you aren't stones - you're men. And, being men, the contents of Caesar's will would enrage you. It's better that you don't know you're his heirs, for if you knew, just imagine what would come of it!

paragraphs.original:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
Read the will. We'll hear it, Antony.
You shall read us the will, Caesar's will.
paragraphs.translated:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
Read the will. We want to hear it, Antony. You have to read us the will, Caesar's will.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Will you be patient? Will you stay awhile?
I have o'ershot myself to tell you of it.
I fear I wrong the honorable men
Whose daggers have stabbed Caesar. I do fear it.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Will you be patient? Will you wait awhile? I've said too much in telling you of it. I'm afraid that I wrong the honorable men whose daggers have stabbed Caesar.

paragraphs.original:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
They were traitors! "Honorable men"!
paragraphs.translated:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
They were traitors. "Honorable men!"

paragraphs.original:
ALL
The will! The testament!
paragraphs.translated:
ALL
The will! The testament!

paragraphs.original:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
They were villains, murderers. The will! Read the will!
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
They were villains, murderers. The will! Read the will!

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
You will compel me, then, to read the will?
Then make a ring about the corpse of Caesar,
And let me show you him that made the will.
Shall I descend? And will you give me leave?
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
You force me to read the will, then? Then make a circle around Caesar's corpse, and let me show you the man who made this will. Shall I come down? Will you let me?

paragraphs.original:
ALL
Come down.
paragraphs.translated:
ALL
Come down.

paragraphs.original:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Descend.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Descend.

paragraphs.original:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
You shall have leave.
paragraphs.translated:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
We'll let you.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY descends from the pulpit
ANTONY
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY descends from the pulpit.
ANTONY

paragraphs.original:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
A ring!
Stand round.
paragraphs.translated:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
Make a circle; stand around him.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Stand from the hearse. Stand from the body.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Stand away from the hearse. Stand away from the body.

paragraphs.original:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Room for Antony, most noble Antony!
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Make room for Antony, most noble Antony!

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Nay, press not so upon me. Stand far off.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
No, don't press up against me. Stand further away.

paragraphs.original:
ALL
Stand back. Room! Bear back.
paragraphs.translated:
ALL
Stand back. Give him room.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
If you have tears, prepare to shed them now.
You all do know this mantle. I remember
The first time ever Caesar put it on.
'Twas on a summer's evening in his tent,
That day he overcame the Nervii.
Look, in this place ran Cassius' dagger through.
See what a rent the envious Casca made.
Through this the well-belovèd Brutus stabbed.
And as he plucked his cursèd steel away,
Mark how the blood of Caesar followed it,
As rushing out of doors, to be resolved
If Brutus so unkindly knocked, or no.
For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar's angel.
Judge, O you gods, how dearly Caesar loved him!
This was the most unkindest cut of all.
For when the noble Caesar saw him stab,
Ingratitude, more strong than traitors' arms,
Quite vanquished him. Then burst his mighty heart,
And, in his mantle muffling up his face,
Even at the base of Pompey's statue,
Which all the while ran blood, great Caesar fell.
O, what a fall was there, my countrymen!
Then I, and you, and all of us fell down,
Whilst bloody treason flourished over us.
Oh, now you weep, and, I perceive, you feel
The dint of pity. These are gracious drops.
Kind souls, what, weep you when you but behold
Our Caesar's vesture wounded? Look you here,
Here is himself, marred, as you see, with traitors.
(lifts up CAESAR's mantle)
(lifts up
s mantle)
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
If you have tears, prepare to shed them now. You all know this cloak. I remember the first time Caesar ever put it on. It was a summer's evening; he was in his tent. It was the day he overcame the Nervii warriors. Look, here's where Cassius's dagger pierced it. See the wound that Casca made. Through this hole beloved Brutus stabbed. And when he pulled out his cursed dagger, see how Caesar's blood came with it, as if rushing out a door to see if it was really Brutus who was knocking so rudely. For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar's angel. The gods know how dearly Caesar loved him! This was the most unkind cut of all. For when the noble Caesar saw him stab, he understood his beloved Brutus's ingratitude; it was stronger than the violence of traitors, and it defeated him, bursting his mighty heart. And at the base of Pompey's statue, with his cloak covering his face, which was dripping with blood the whole time, great Caesar fell. Oh, what a fall it was, my countrymen! Then you and I and all of us fell down, while bloody treason triumphed. Oh, now you weep, and I sense that you feel pity. These are gracious tears. But if it overwhelms you to look at Caesar's wounded cloak, how will you feel, kind men, now? Look at this, here is the man - scarred, as you can see, by traitors. (he lifts up CAESAR's cloak)
(he lifts up
s cloak)

paragraphs.original:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
O piteous spectacle!
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Oh, what a sad sight!

paragraphs.original:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
O noble Caesar!
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Oh, noble Caesar!

paragraphs.original:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
O woeful day!
paragraphs.translated:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Oh, sad day!

paragraphs.original:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
O traitors, villains!
paragraphs.translated:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
Oh, traitors, villains!

paragraphs.original:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
O most bloody sight!
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Oh, most bloody sight!

paragraphs.original:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
We will be revenged.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
We will get revenge.

paragraphs.original:
ALL
Revenge! About! Seek! Burn! Fire! Kill! Slay!
Let not a traitor live!
paragraphs.translated:
ALL
Revenge! Let's go after them! Seek! Burn! Set fire! Kill! Slay! Leave no traitors alive!

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Stay, countrymen.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Wait, countrymen.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Peace there! Hear the noble Antony.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Quiet there! Listen to the noble Antony.

paragraphs.original:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
We'll hear him. We'll follow him. We'll die with him.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
We'll listen to him, we'll follow him, we'll die with him.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Good friends, sweet friends! Let me not stir you up
To such a sudden flood of mutiny.
They that have done this deed are honorable.
What private griefs they have, alas, I know not,
That made them do it. They are wise and honorable,
And will, no doubt, with reasons answer you.
I come not, friends, to steal away your hearts.
I am no orator, as Brutus is,
But, as you know me all, a plain blunt man
That love my friend. And that they know full well
That gave me public leave to speak of him.
For I have neither wit nor words nor worth,
Action nor utterance nor the power of speech,
To stir men's blood. I only speak right on.
I tell you that which you yourselves do know,
Show you sweet Caesar's wounds, poor poor dumb mouths,
And bid them speak for me. But were I Brutus,
And Brutus Antony, there were an Antony
Would ruffle up your spirits and put a tongue
In every wound of Caesar that should move
The stones of Rome to rise and mutiny.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Good friends, sweet friends, don't let me stir you up to such a sudden mutiny. Those who have done this deed are honorable. I don't know what private grudges they had that made them do it. They're wise and honorable, and will no doubt give you reasons for it. I haven't come to steal your loyalty, friends. I'm no orator, as Brutus is. I'm only, as you know, a plain, blunt man who loved his friend, and the men who let me speak know this well. I have neither cleverness nor rhetorical skill nor the authority nor gesture nor eloquence nor the power of speech to stir men up. I just speak directly. I tell you what you already know. I show you sweet Caesar's wounds - poor, speechless mouths! - and make them speak for me. But if I were Brutus and Brutus were me, then I'd stir you up, and install in each of Caesar's wounds the kind of voice that could convince even stones to rise up and mutiny.

paragraphs.original:
ALL
We'll mutiny.
paragraphs.translated:
ALL
We'll mutiny.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
We'll burn the house of Brutus.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
We'll burn Brutus's house.

paragraphs.original:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Away, then! Come, seek the conspirators.
paragraphs.translated:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Let's go, then! Come, find the conspirators!

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Yet hear me, countrymen. Yet hear me speak.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Wait, and listen to me, countrymen.

paragraphs.original:
ALL
Peace, ho! Hear Antony. Most noble Antony!
paragraphs.translated:
ALL
Quiet! Wait! Listen to Antony. Most noble Antony!

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Why, friends, you go to do you know not what.
Wherein hath Caesar thus deserved your loves?
Alas, you know not. I must tell you then.
You have forgot the will I told you of.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Why, friends, you don't even know what you're doing yet. What has Caesar done to deserve your love? Alas, you don't know. I must tell you then. You've forgotten the will I told you about.

paragraphs.original:
ALL
Most true. The will! Let's stay and hear the will.
paragraphs.translated:
ALL
Yes! The will! Let's stay and hear the will!

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Here is the will, and under Caesar's seal
To every Roman citizen he gives - 
To every several man - seventy-five drachmas.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Here's the will, written under Caesar's seal. To every Roman citizen he gives - to every individual man - seventy-five drachmas.

paragraphs.original:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Most noble Caesar! We'll revenge his death.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Most noble Caesar! We'll revenge his death.

paragraphs.original:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
O royal Caesar!
paragraphs.translated:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Oh, royal Caesar!

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Hear me with patience.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Listen to me patiently.

paragraphs.original:
ALL
Peace, ho!
paragraphs.translated:
ALL
Quiet, there!

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Moreover, he hath left you all his walks,
His private arbors and new-planted orchards,
On this side Tiber. He hath left them you
And to your heirs forever - common pleasures,
To walk abroad and recreate yourselves.
Here was a Caesar! When comes such another?
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Also, he's left you all his walkways - in his private gardens and newly planted orchards - on this side of the Tiber River. He's left them to you and to your heirs forever - public pleasures in which you will be able to stroll and relax. Here was a Caesar! When will there be another like him?

paragraphs.original:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Never, never. - Come, away, away!
We'll burn his body in the holy place,
And with the brands fire the traitors' houses.
Take up the body.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Never, never. Let's go! We'll burn his body in the holy place and use the brands to set the traitors' houses on fire. Take up the body.

paragraphs.original:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Go fetch fire.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
We'll start a fire.

paragraphs.original:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Pluck down benches.
paragraphs.translated:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
We'll use benches for wood -

paragraphs.original:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
Pluck down forms, windows, anything.
paragraphs.translated:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
And windowsills, anything.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt PLEBEIANS with CAESAR's body
PLEBEIANS
CAESAR
paragraphs.translated:
Citizens exit with CAESAR's body.
CAESAR

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Now let it work. Mischief, thou art afoot.
Take thou what course thou wilt!
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Now, let it work. Trouble, you have begun - take whatever course you choose!

paragraphs.original:
Enter OCTAVIUS' SERVANT
OCTAVIUS' SERVANT
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT enters.
OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT

paragraphs.original: How now, fellow?
paragraphs.translated: What's up, my man?

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS' SERVANT
Sir, Octavius is already come to Rome.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT
Sir, Octavius has already arrived in Rome.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Where is he?
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Where is he?

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS' SERVANT
He and Lepidus are at Caesar's house.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT
He and Lepidus are at Caesar's house.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
And thither will I straight to visit him.
He comes upon a wish. Fortune is merry,
And in this mood will give us anything.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
I will go straight to visit him. I ask for him, and he comes. Fortune is happy today and, in this mood, will give us anything we want.

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS' SERVANT
I heard him say, Brutus and Cassius
Are rid like madmen through the gates of Rome.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS'S SERVANT
I heard Octavius say that Brutus and Cassius have ridden like madmen through the gates of Rome.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Belike they had some notice of the people
How I had moved them. Bring me to Octavius.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
They probably received warning about how much I stirred up the people. Take me to Octavius.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Enter CINNA THE POET, and after him the PLEBEIANS
CINNA THE POET
PLEBEIANS
paragraphs.translated:
CINNA THE POET enters, followed by PLEBEIANS.
CINNA THE POET
PLEBEIANS

paragraphs.original:
CINNA THE POET
I dreamt tonight that I did feast with Caesar,
And things unlucky charge my fantasy.
I have no will to wander forth of doors,
Yet something leads me forth.
paragraphs.translated:
CINNA THE POET
I dreamed last night that I feasted with Caesar, and unlucky signs overwhelmed my imagination. I have no desire to go outside, yet something leads me there.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
What is your name?
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
What's your name?

paragraphs.original:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Whither are you going?
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Where are you going?

paragraphs.original:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Where do you dwell?
paragraphs.translated:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Where do you live?

paragraphs.original:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
Are you a married man or a bachelor?
paragraphs.translated:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
Are you a married man or a bachelor?

paragraphs.original:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Answer every man directly.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
Answer all of us, now.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Ay, and briefly.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Yes, and be brief.

paragraphs.original:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
Ay, and wisely.
paragraphs.translated:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
Yes, and be wise.

paragraphs.original:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Ay, and truly, you were best.
paragraphs.translated:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Yes, and be truthful, if you know what's good for you.

paragraphs.original:
CINNA THE POET
What is my name? Whither am I going? Where do I dwell? Am I a married man or a bachelor? Then, to answer every man directly and briefly, wisely and truly - wisely I say, I am a bachelor.
paragraphs.translated:
CINNA THE POET
What's my name? Where am I going? Where do I live? Am I a married man or a bachelor? Then, to answer every man briefly, wisely, and truthfully - wisely I say, I am a bachelor.

paragraphs.original:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
That's as much as to say they are fools that marry. You'll bear me a bang for that, I fear. Proceed, directly.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
You imply that married men are fools. You'll get a blow from me for that, I think. Go on with what you were saying - right this instant.

paragraphs.original:
CINNA THE POET
Directly, I am going to Caesar's funeral.
paragraphs.translated:
CINNA THE POET
Right this instant, I'm going to Caesar's funeral.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
As a friend or an enemy?
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
As a friend or an enemy?

paragraphs.original:
CINNA THE POET
As a friend.
paragraphs.translated:
CINNA THE POET
As a friend.

paragraphs.original:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
That matter is answered directly.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND PLEBEIAN
He answered that question straight.

paragraphs.original:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
For your dwelling - briefly.
paragraphs.translated:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
As for where you live, tell us quickly - get to the point.

paragraphs.original:
CINNA THE POET
Briefly, I dwell by the Capitol.
paragraphs.translated:
CINNA THE POET
Getting right to the point, I live near the Capitol.

paragraphs.original:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Your name, sir, truly.
paragraphs.translated:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Tell us your name, sir, truthfully.

paragraphs.original:
CINNA THE POET
Truly, my name is Cinna.
paragraphs.translated:
CINNA THE POET
Truthfully, my name is Cinna.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Tear him to pieces. He's a conspirator.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST PLEBEIAN
Tear him to pieces. He's a conspirator.

paragraphs.original:
CINNA THE POET
I am Cinna the poet. I am Cinna the poet.
paragraphs.translated:
CINNA THE POET
I am Cinna the poet, I am Cinna the poet!

paragraphs.original:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
Tear him for his bad verses! Tear him for his bad verses!
paragraphs.translated:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
Tear him apart for his bad verses, tear him up!

paragraphs.original:
CINNA THE POET
I am not Cinna the conspirator.
paragraphs.translated:
CINNA THE POET
I'm not Cinna the conspirator.

paragraphs.original:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
It is no matter. His name's Cinna. Pluck but his name out of his heart and turn him going.
paragraphs.translated:
FOURTH PLEBEIAN
It doesn't matter. His name's Cinna. Pull only his name out of his heart and let him go.

paragraphs.original:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Tear him, tear him!
paragraphs.translated:
THIRD PLEBEIAN
Tear him apart, tear him up!

paragraphs.original:
PLEBEIANS attack CINNA THE POET
PLEBEIANS
CINNA THE POET
paragraphs.translated:
The PLEBEIANS attack CINNA THE POET.
PLEBEIANS
CINNA THE POET

paragraphs.original:
ALL
Come, brands, ho, firebrands. To Brutus', to Cassius', burn all. Some to Decius' house and some to Casca's. Some to Ligarius'. Away, go!
paragraphs.translated:
ALL
Come, firebrands, over here! To Brutus's, to Cassius's, let's burn them all. Some of you go to Decius's house and some to Casca's. Some to Ligarius's. Go!

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt PLEBEIANS dragging CINNA THE POET
PLEBEIANS
CINNA THE POET
paragraphs.translated:
The PLEBEIANS exit, dragging CINNA THE POET.
PLEBEIANS
CINNA THE POET

paragraphs.original:
Enter ANTONY, OCTAVIUS, and LEPIDUS
ANTONY
OCTAVIUS
LEPIDUS
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY, OCTAVIUS, and LEPIDUS enter.
ANTONY
OCTAVIUS
LEPIDUS

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
These many, then, shall die. Their names are pricked.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
These ones, then, will be assassinated. Their names are marked.

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
(to LEPIDUS)
(to
)
Your brother too must die. Consent you, Lepidus?
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
(to LEPIDUS) Your brother has to die too. Do you agree, Lepidus?
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
LEPIDUS
I do consent -
paragraphs.translated:
LEPIDUS
I agree -

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
Prick him down, Antony.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
Put a mark next to his name too, Antony.

paragraphs.original:
LEPIDUS
Upon condition Publius shall not live,
Who is your sister's son, Mark Antony.
paragraphs.translated:
LEPIDUS
On the condition that your sister's son, Publius, also must die, Mark Antony.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
He shall not live. Look, with a spot I damn him.
But, Lepidus, go you to Caesar's house.
Fetch the will hither, and we shall determine
How to cut off some charge in legacies.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
He will die. See - I've sealed his fate with this mark next to his name. But, Lepidus, go to Caesar's house. Bring his will here, and we'll figure out a way to reduce his bequests to the people.

paragraphs.original:
LEPIDUS
What, shall I find you here?
paragraphs.translated:
LEPIDUS
Will you be here when I return?

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
Or here, or at the Capitol.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
Either here or at the Capitol.

paragraphs.original:
Exit LEPIDUS
LEPIDUS
paragraphs.translated:
LEPIDUS exits.
LEPIDUS

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
This is a slight, unmeritable man,
Meet to be sent on errands. Is it fit,
The threefold world divided, he should stand
One of the three to share it?
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
He's an unremarkable man, fit only to be sent on errands. Does it really make sense, once we divide the world into three parts, that he should be one of the three rulers?

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
So you thought him.
And took his voice who should be pricked to die
In our black sentence and proscription.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
You thought it made sense, and you listened to him about who should be marked to die in these harsh death sentences.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Octavius, I have seen more days than you.
And though we lay these honors on this man
To ease ourselves of divers slanderous loads,
He shall but bear them as the ass bears gold,
To groan and sweat under the business,
Either led or driven, as we point the way.
And having brought our treasure where we will,
Then take we down his load and turn him off,
Like to the empty ass, to shake his ears
And graze in commons.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Octavius, I'm older than you are. And although we're giving these honors to this man so that he shares some of the blame for what we're doing, he'll carry these honors like a jackass carries gold - groaning and sweating under the load, either led or pushed, as we direct him. Once he's carried our treasure where we want it, we'll free him of the load and turn him loose like a jackass, to shake his ears and graze in the public pastures.

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
You may do your will,
But he's a tried and valiant soldier.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
You can do what you want, but he's an experienced and honorable soldier.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
So is my horse, Octavius, and for that
I do appoint him store of provender.
It is a creature that I teach to fight,
To wind, to stop, to run directly on,
His corporal motion governed by my spirit,
And, in some taste, is Lepidus but so.
He must be taught and trained and bid go forth,
A barren-spirited fellow, one that feeds
On objects, arts, and imitations,
Which, out of use and staled by other men,
Begin his fashion. Do not talk of him
But as a property. And now, Octavius,
Listen great things. Brutus and Cassius
Are levying powers. We must straight make head.
Therefore let our alliance be combined,
Our best friends made, our means stretched.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
So is my horse, Octavius, and for that reason I give him all the hay he wants. But my horse is a creature that I teach to fight - to turn, to stop, to run in a straight line. I govern the motion of his body. And in some ways, Lepidus is just like that. He has to be taught and trained and told to go forward. He's an empty man, who pays attention to fashions and tastes that other men took up and got tired of long ago. Don't think about Lepidus except as a means to an end. And now, Octavius, listen to more important things. Brutus and Cassius are raising armies. We have to raise our own immediately. So, we should combine forces and organize our allies, pull together our friends, and stretch our resources as far as they'll go.
I

paragraphs.original:
And let us presently go sit in council
How covert matters may be best disclosed,
And open perils surest answered.
paragraphs.translated: Let's immediately organize a council to discuss the best way to find out their secrets and the safest way to confront the threats we're already faced with.

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
Let us do so. For we are at the stake
And bayed about with many enemies.
And some that smile have in their hearts, I fear,
Millions of mischiefs.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
Let's do that, because we're hemmed in by many enemies. And even some of the people who smile at us are in fact plotting against us, I'm afraid.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original:
Drum. Enter BRUTUS with LUCIUS, LUCILLIUS, and the army. TITINIUS and PINDARUS meet them
BRUTUS
LUCIUS
LUCILLIUS
TITINIUS
PINDARUS
paragraphs.translated:
A drum plays. BRUTUS, LUCILLIUS, LUCIUS, and SOLDIERS enter. TITINIUS and PINDARUS meet them.
BRUTUS
LUCILLIUS
LUCIUS
SOLDIERS
TITINIUS
PINDARUS

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Stand, ho!
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Stop.

paragraphs.original:
LUCILLIUS
Give the word, ho, and stand.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCILLIUS
Pass on the command to halt!

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
What now, Lucillius? Is Cassius near?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
What's happening now, Lucillius? Is Cassius nearby?

paragraphs.original:
LUCILLIUS
He is at hand, and Pindarus is come
To do you salutation from his master.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCILLIUS
He's nearby, and Pindarus has come to salute you on behalf of his master.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
He greets me well. - Your master, Pindarus,
In his own change or by ill officers
Hath given me some worthy cause to wish
Things done, undone. But if he be at hand
I shall be satisfied.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
He sends his greetings through a good man. Your master, Pindarus, either because he's changed his mind or been influenced by bad officers, has made me wish we hadn't done some of the things we did. If he's nearby, I want an explanation.

paragraphs.original:
PINDARUS
I do not doubt
But that my noble master will appear
Such as he is, full of regard and honor.
paragraphs.translated:
PINDARUS
I have no doubt that my noble master will prove himself to be what he is: honorable and noble.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
He is not doubted. - A word, Lucillius.
(takes LUCILLIUS aside)
(takes
aside)
How he received you, let me be resolved.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
I don't doubt him. Can I have a word with you, Lucillius? (takes LUCILLIUS aside) Tell me how Cassius treated you. Put my mind at rest.
(takes
aside)

paragraphs.original:
LUCILLIUS
With courtesy and with respect enough.
But not with such familiar instances
Nor with such free and friendly conference
As he hath used of old.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCILLIUS
He received me with courtesy and sufficient respect, but not with affection, nor with as much open and friendly conversation as he once greeted me.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Thou hast described
A hot friend cooling. Ever note, Lucillius,
When love begins to sicken and decay,
It useth an enforcèd ceremony.
There are no tricks in plain and simple faith.
But hollow men, like horses hot at hand,
Make gallant show and promise of their mettle.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
You've described a warm friend who's cooling off. Remember this, Lucillius. When a friend starts to get sick of you, he treats you artificially. Plain and simple loyalty doesn't make anyone act phony. But insincere men, like horses who are too lively at the start of a race, make a big show of their spirit.

paragraphs.original: Low march within
paragraphs.translated:
A low sound of drums and SOLDIERS marching.
SOLDIERS

paragraphs.original:
But when they should endure the bloody spur,
They fall their crests and, like deceitful jades,
Sink in the trial. Comes his army on?
paragraphs.translated: But when push comes to shove, they droop like those horses that are all show and slow to a crawl. Is his army approaching?

paragraphs.original:
LUCILLIUS
They mean this night in Sardis to be quartered.
The greater part, the horse in general,
Are come with Cassius.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCILLIUS
They plan to spend the night in Sardis. The larger part, the main body of cavalry, are coming with Cassius.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Hark! He is arrived.
March gently on to meet him.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Look! He's arrived. March to meet him at a dignified pace.

paragraphs.original:
Enter CASSIUS and his powers
CASSIUS
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS enters with his army.
CASSIUS

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Stand, ho!
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Halt.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Stand, ho! Speak the word along.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Halt! Pass the order along.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST SOLDIER
Stand!
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST SOLDIER
Halt!

paragraphs.original:
SECOND SOLDIER
Stand!
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND SOLDIER
Halt!

paragraphs.original:
THIRD SOLDIER
Stand!
paragraphs.translated:
THIRD SOLDIER
Halt!

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Most noble brother, you have done me wrong.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Most noble brother, you have done me wrong.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Judge me, you gods! Wrong I mine enemies?
And if not so, how should I wrong a brother?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Let the gods judge me! Do I mistreat even my enemies? No. So how could I possibly wrong a brother?

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Brutus, this sober form of yours hides wrongs.
And when you do them -
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Brutus, your sober expression is a mask to hide the fact that you've wronged me. And when you do -

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Cassius, be content.
Speak your griefs softly. I do know you well.
Before the eyes of both our armies here,
Which should perceive nothing but love from us,
Let us not wrangle. Bid them move away.
Then in my tent, Cassius, enlarge your griefs,
And I will give you audience.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Cassius, calm down. We know each other well, and you can speak your grievances quietly. Let's not argue here in front of both our armies, which ought to see nothing but love between us. Order them to move back. Then, in my tent, you can elaborate on your complaints, and I'll listen.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Pindarus,
Bid our commanders lead their charges off
A little from this ground.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Pindarus, order our commanders to lead their charges a little ways away from this ground.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Lucillius, do you the like. And let no man
Come to our tent till we have done our conference.
Let Lucius and Titinius guard our door.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Lucillius, you do the same, and don't allow anyone to come into our tent until we've finished our conference. Have Lucius and Titinius guard the door.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated:
Everyone except BRUTUS and CASSIUS exits.
BRUTUS
CASSIUS

paragraphs.original:
Manent BRUTUS and CASSIUS, now in the tent
BRUTUS
CASSIUS
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS and CASSIUS remain onstage. They are now in their tent.
BRUTUS
CASSIUS

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
That you have wronged me doth appear in this:
You have condemned and noted Lucius Pella
For taking bribes here of the Sardians,
Wherein my letters, praying on his side
Because I knew the man, were slighted off.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
My evidence that you have wronged me is that you condemned and disgraced Lucius Pella for taking bribes here from the Sardinians, and you ignored my letters, where I argued that he was innocent; I know the man.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
You wronged yourself to write in such a case.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
You wronged yourself to write on behalf of such a man.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
In such a time as this it is not meet
That every nice offense should bear his comment.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
In a time like this, it doesn't make sense to criticize every offense.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Let me tell you, Cassius, you yourself
Are much condemned to have an itching palm,
To sell and mart your offices for gold
To undeservers.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
I'll tell you, Cassius, you yourself have been called greedy and been accused of giving your positions to undeserving men in exchange for gold.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
I "an itching palm"!
You know that you are Brutus that speak this,
Or, by the gods, this speech were else your last.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Me, "greedy"! You know, if you were anyone other than Brutus, that speech would be your last.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
The name of Cassius honors this corruption,
And chastisement doth therefore hide his head.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
The name of Cassius gives credit to these corrupt actions, and so they go unpunished.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Chastisement!
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Unpunished!

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Remember March, the ides of March remember.
Did not great Julius bleed for justice' sake?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Remember March, March 15th. Didn't great Caesar bleed for the sake of justice?

paragraphs.original:
What villain touched his body, that did stab,
And not for justice? What, shall one of us
That struck the foremost man of all this world
But for supporting robbers, shall we now
Contaminate our fingers with base bribes,
And sell the mighty space of our large honors
For so much trash as may be graspèd thus?
I had rather be a dog and bay the moon
Than such a Roman.
paragraphs.translated: Who among us stabbed him for any cause but justice? What - did one of us strike down the most powerful man in the world in order to support robbers? Should we now dirty our fingers with lowly bribes and sell the mighty offices that we hold for whatever money we can get our hands on? I'd rather be a dog and howl at the moon than be that kind of Roman.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Brutus, bait not me.
I'll not endure it. You forget yourself
To hedge me in. I am a soldier, I,
Older in practice, abler than yourself
To make conditions.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Brutus, do not provoke me. I will not take it. You're forgetting yourself when you back me into a corner. I'm a soldier, more experienced than you, and better able to give orders.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Go to. You are not, Cassius.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Get lost! You are not, Cassius.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
I am.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
I am.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
I say you are not.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
I say you're not.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Urge me no more, I shall forget myself.
Have mind upon your health, tempt me no further.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Don't provoke me any further or I'll forget to restrain myself. If you care about your health, you won't push me any further.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Away, slight man!
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Leave, you little man.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Is 't possible?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Is this possible?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Hear me, for I will speak.
Must I give way and room to your rash choler?
Shall I be frighted when a madman stares?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Listen to me, for I have something to tell you. Am I required to indulge your rash anger? Does a madman scare me when he stares at me?

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
O ye gods, ye gods, must I endure all this?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Oh gods, oh gods! Must I endure all this?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
"All this"? Ay, more. Fret till your proud heart break.
Go show your slaves how choleric you are
And make your bondmen tremble. Must I budge?
Must I observe you? Must I stand and crouch
Under your testy humor? By the gods,
You shall digest the venom of your spleen,
Though it do split you. For from this day forth,
I'll use you for my mirth, yea, for my laughter,
When you are waspish.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
"All this"? Yes, and more. Go ahead - rage till your proud heart breaks. Show your slaves how mad you are, and make your servants tremble. But me - am I going to cower at you and your irritable moods? You'll have to swallow your own poison till it makes you burst before I'm going to respond; from now on, I'll make you the butt of my jokes whenever you get sharp with me.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Is it come to this?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Has it come to this?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
You say you are a better soldier.
Let it appear so. Make your vaunting true,
And it shall please me well. For mine own part,
I shall be glad to learn of noble men.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
You say you're a better soldier. Show it! Make your boasts come true, and I'll be thrilled. I'm always happy to hear about brave men.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
You wrong me every way. You wrong me, Brutus.
I said an elder soldier, not a better.
Did I say "better"?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
You wrong me in every way. You wrong me, Brutus. I said an older soldier, not a better one. Did I say "better"?
older

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
If you did, I care not.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
If you did, I don't care.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
When Caesar lived, he durst not thus have moved me.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
When Caesar was alive, even he wouldn't dare anger me like this.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Peace, peace! You durst not so have tempted him.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Oh, be quiet. You wouldn't have dared to tempt him so.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
I durst not!
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
I wouldn't have dared!

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
No.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
No.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
What, durst not tempt him?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
What? Not dared to tempt him?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
For your life you durst not.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
You wouldn't have dared, out of fear for your life.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Do not presume too much upon my love.
I may do that I shall be sorry for.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Don't take my love for granted. I might do something I'll be sorry for.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
You have done that you should be sorry for.
There is no terror, Cassius, in your threats,
For I am armed so strong in honesty
That they pass by me as the idle wind,
Which I respect not. I did send to you
For certain sums of gold, which you denied me,
For I can raise no money by vile means.
By heaven, I had rather coin my heart
And drop my blood for drachmas than to wring
From the hard hands of peasants their vile trash
By any indirection. I did send
To you for gold to pay my legions,
Which you denied me. Was that done like Cassius?
Should I have answered Caius Cassius so?
When Marcus Brutus grows so covetous
To lock such rascal counters from his friends,
Be ready, gods, with all your thunderbolts.
Dash him to pieces!
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
You've already done something you should be sorry for. Your threats don't scare me, Cassius, because I'm so secure in my honesty and integrity that they pass me by like a weak breeze. I asked you for a certain amount of gold, which you wouldn't give me. I myself can't raise money by unethical means. I'd rather turn my heart into money and my drops of blood into coins than use crooked tactics to wring petty cash from the hardworking hands of peasants. I asked you for gold to pay my soldiers, and you wouldn't give it to me. Was that the Caius Cassius that I knew? And would I have ever done that to you? If I ever get so greedy that I hoard such petty cash from my friends, may the gods dash me to pieces with their thunderbolts!

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
I denied you not.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
I didn't refuse you.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
You did.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
You did.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
I did not. He was but a fool that brought
My answer back. Brutus hath rived my heart.
A friend should bear his friend's infirmities,
But Brutus makes mine greater than they are.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
I didn't. The man who brought my answer to you was a fool. You have broken my heart. A friend should put up with his friend's weaknesses, but you exaggerate mine.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
I do not, till you practice them on me.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
I don't until you practice them on me.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
You love me not.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
You don't love me.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
I do not like your faults.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
I don't like your faults.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
A friendly eye could never see such faults.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
A friend would never see those faults.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
A flatterer's would not, though they do appear
As huge as high Olympus.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
No, a flatterer wouldn't, even if the faults were as huge as Mount Olympus.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Come, Antony, and young Octavius, come,
Revenge yourselves alone on Cassius,
For Cassius is aweary of the world - 
Hated by one he loves; braved by his brother;
Checked like a bondman, all his faults observed,
Set in a notebook, learned, and conned by rote
To cast into my teeth. Oh, I could weep
My spirit from mine eyes.
(offers BRUTUS his bared dagger) There is my dagger.
(offers
his bared dagger)
And here my naked breast. Within, a heart
Dearer than Plutus' mine, richer than gold.
If that thou beest a Roman, take it forth.
I, that denied thee gold, will give my heart.
Strike, as thou didst at Caesar. For I know
When thou didst hate him worst, thou lovedst him better
Than ever thou lovedst Cassius.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Come, Antony and young Octavius! Get your revenge on Cassius, because Cassius has grown tired of the world. He's hated by someone he loves, defied by his brother, rebuked like a servant, all his faults observed, catalogued in a notebook, read, and committed to memory so they can be thrown in his face. Oh, I could weep my soul right out of myself! There's my dagger (he offers BRUTUS his unsheathed dagger), and here's my bare chest. Inside it is a heart more valuable than
Pluto's silver mine and richer than gold. If you're a Roman, take my heart out. I, who denied you gold, will give you my heart. Strike as you did at Caesar, for I know even when you hated him the most, you still loved him better than you ever loved me.
(he offers
his unsheathed dagger)
Pluto's

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Sheathe your dagger.
Be angry when you will, it shall have scope.
Do what you will, dishonor shall be humor.
O Cassius, you are yokèd with a lamb
That carries anger as the flint bears fire,
Who, much enforcèd, shows a hasty spark
And straight is cold again.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Put away your dagger. Be angry whenever you like, it's all right with me. Do whatever you want, and I'll say your insults are just a bad mood. Oh, Cassius, you're partners with a quiet lamb. My anger is like a flint striking - a brief spark, and then I'm cold again.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Hath Cassius lived
To be but mirth and laughter to his Brutus,
When grief and blood ill-tempered vexeth him?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Have I lived this long only to be the butt of a joke whenever you're angry or frustrated?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
When I spoke that, I was ill-tempered too.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
When I said that, I was angry too.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Do you confess so much? Give me your hand.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
You admit it, then? Give me your hand.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
And my heart too.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
And my heart too.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS and BRUTUS shake hands
CASSIUS
BRUTUS
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS and BRUTUS shake hands.
CASSIUS
BRUTUS

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
O Brutus!
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Oh, Brutus!

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
What's the matter?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
What's the matter?

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Have not you love enough to bear with me,
When that rash humor which my mother gave me
Makes me forgetful?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Do you have enough love for me to be patient when my bad temper, which I inherited from my mother, makes me forget how I should behave?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Yes, Cassius. And from henceforth
When you are over-earnest with your Brutus,
He'll think your mother chides and leave you so.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Yes, Cassius. And from now on, when you get hot with me, I'll assume it's your mother speaking and leave it at that.

paragraphs.original:
POET
(within) Let me go in to see the generals.
(within)
There is some grudge between 'em. 'Tis not meet
They be alone.
paragraphs.translated:
POET
(offstage) Let me in to see the generals. There's a grudge between them, and it isn't a good idea for them to be alone.
(offstage)

paragraphs.original:
LUCILLIUS
(within)    You shall not come to them.
(within)
paragraphs.translated:
LUCILLIUS
(offstage) You can't see them.
(offstage)

paragraphs.original:
POET
(within) Nothing but death shall stay me.
(within)
paragraphs.translated:
POET
(offstage) You'd have to kill me to stop me.
(offstage)

paragraphs.original:
Enter a POET followed by LUCILLIUS and TITINIUS
POET
LUCILLIUS
TITINIUS
paragraphs.translated:
A POET enters, followed by LUCILLIUS and TITINIUS.
POET
LUCILLIUS
TITINIUS

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
How now? What's the matter?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
What's this! What's the matter?

paragraphs.original:
POET
For shame, you generals! What do you mean?
Love, and be friends as two such men should be.
For I have seen more years, I'm sure, than ye.
paragraphs.translated:
POET
You should be ashamed, generals! What do you think you're doing?
Love each other and be friends, like two such men should be.
Listen to me, because I'm older than you, surely.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Ha, ha, how vilely doth this cynic rhyme!
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Ha ha! This man's rhymes are terrible!

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
(to POET) Get you hence, sirrah. Saucy fellow, hence!
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
(to POET) Get out of here, you! Get away, you rude fellow!
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Bear with him, Brutus. 'Tis his fashion.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Be patient with him, Brutus. That's just how he is.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
I'll know his humor when he knows his time.
What should the wars do with these jigging fools?
 - Companion, hence!
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
I'll humor him when he learns how to behave. What should we do with all these rhyming fools that follow us from post to post? Get out of here, my friend.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Away, away, be gone.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Away, away, be gone.

paragraphs.original:
Exit POET
POET
paragraphs.translated:
The POET exits.
POET

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Lucillius and Titinius, bid the commanders
Prepare to lodge their companies tonight.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Lucillius and Titinius, order the commanders to have the men camp for the night.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
And come yourselves, and bring Messala with you,
Immediately to us.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
And return to us immediately, bringing Messala with you.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt LUCILLIUS and TITINIUS
LUCILLIUS
TITINIUS
paragraphs.translated:
LUCILLIUS and TITINIUS exit.
LUCILLIUS
TITINIUS

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
(calls off)    Lucius, a bowl of wine!
(calls off)
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
(calling offstage) Lucius, bring a bowl of wine.
(calling offstage)

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
I did not think you could have been so angry.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
I didn't think you could even be so angry.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
O Cassius, I am sick of many griefs.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Oh Cassius, I'm tired out by many sorrows.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Of your philosophy you make no use
If you give place to accidental evils.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
You're forgetting your
Stoic philosophy if you allow chance misfortunes to upset you.
Stoic

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
No man bears sorrow better. Portia is dead.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
No one bears sorrow better than me. Portia is dead.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Ha, Portia?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Portia!

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
She is dead.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
She is dead.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
How 'scaped I killing when I crossed you so?
O insupportable and touching loss!
Upon what sickness?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
How did you manage not to kill me when we argued just now? What an irreplaceable and grievous loss! What sickness did she die of?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Impatient of my absence,
And grief that young Octavius with Mark Antony
Have made themselves so strong - for with her death
That tidings came - with this she fell distract
And, her attendants absent, swallowed fire.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
She was worried about my absence, and about the fact that young Octavius and Mark Antony have grown so strong - which I found out at the same time as the news of her death. She became full of despair and, when her attendants were away, swallowed burning coals.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
And died so?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
And that's how she died?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Even so.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Yes, like that.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
O ye immortal gods!
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Oh, immortal gods!

paragraphs.original:
Enter LUCIUS with wine and tapers
LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS enters with wine and candles.
LUCIUS

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Speak no more of her. - Give me a bowl of wine. - 
In this I bury all unkindness, Cassius.
(drinks)
(drinks)
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Don't talk about her anymore. Give me a bowl of wine. With this toast I bury all bad feelings between us, Cassius. (he drinks)
(he drinks)

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
My heart is thirsty for that noble pledge.
Fill, Lucius, till the wine o'erswell the cup.
I cannot drink too much of Brutus' love.
(drinks)
(drinks)
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
My heart is thirsty for that noble promise. Fill my cup, Lucius, until the wine overflows it. I cannot drink too much of Brutus's love. (he drinks)
(he drinks)

paragraphs.original:
Exit LUCIUS
LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS exits.
LUCIUS

paragraphs.original:
Enter TITINIUS and MESSALA
TITINIUS
MESSALA
paragraphs.translated:
TITINIUS and MESSALA enter.
TITINIUS
MESSALA

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Come in, Titinius. - Welcome, good Messala!
Now sit we close about this taper here
And call in question our necessities.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Come in, Titinius! Welcome, good Messala. Now let's sit closely around this candle and discuss our needs.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Portia, art thou gone?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Portia, are you really gone?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
No more, I pray you.
 - Messala, I have here receivèd letters
That young Octavius and Mark Antony
Come down upon us with a mighty power,
Bending their expedition toward Philippi.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
No more about that, please. Messala, I have received these letters explaining that young Octavius and Mark Antony are rushing toward Philippi and bearing down upon us with a mighty power.

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
Myself have letters of the selfsame tenor.
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
I have received letters that say the same.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
With what addition?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
And anything else?

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
That by proscription and bills of outlawry,
Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus
Have put to death an hundred senators.
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
That with a series of legal writs, Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus have put a hundred senators to death.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Therein our letters do not well agree.
Mine speak of seventy senators that died
By their proscriptions, Cicero being one.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
On that point, our letters don't agree. My letters say only seventy senators were killed, one being Cicero.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Cicero one?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Cicero too?

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
Cicero is dead,
And by that order of proscription.
(to BRUTUS) Had you your letters from your wife, my lord?
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
Cicero is dead, by their decree. (to BRUTUS) Have you received letters from your wife, my lord?
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
No, Messala.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
No, Messala.

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
Nor nothing in your letters writ of her?
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
And you haven't heard any news about her in your letters?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Nothing, Messala.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Nothing, Messala.

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
That methinks is strange.
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
I think that's strange.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Why ask you? Hear you aught of her in yours?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Why do you ask? Have you heard something of her in your letters?

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
No, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
No, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Now, as you are a Roman, tell me true.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Now, as you're a Roman, tell me the truth.

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
Then like a Roman bear the truth I tell.
For certain she is dead, and by strange manner.
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
Then you must take the truth I have to tell like a Roman. It's certain that she is dead, and she died in a strange way.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Why, farewell, Portia. We must die, Messala.
With meditating that she must die once,
I have the patience to endure it now.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Well, good-bye, Portia. We all must die, Messala. Having already thought about the fact that she would have to die sometime, I can endure her death now.

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
Even so great men great losses should endure.
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
That's the way great men ought to endure great losses.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
I have as much of this in art as you,
But yet my nature could not bear it so.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
I've practiced Stoicism with as much devotion as you, but I still couldn't bear this news like you do.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Well, to our work alive. What do you think
Of marching to Philippi presently?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Well, let's move on to our work with the living. What do you think of marching to Philippi immediately?

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
I do not think it good.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
I don't think it's a good idea.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Your reason?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Why not?

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
This it is:
'Tis better that the enemy seek us.
So shall he waste his means, weary his soldiers,
Doing himself offense, whilst we, lying still,
Are full of rest, defense, and nimbleness.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Here's why: it'd be better for the enemy to come after us. That way, he'll waste his provisions and tire out his soldiers, weakening his own capacities, while we, lying still, are rested, energetic, and nimble.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Good reasons must of force give place to better.
The people 'twixt Philippi and this ground
Do stand but in a forced affection,
For they have grudged us contribution.
The enemy, marching along by them,
By them shall make a fuller number up,
Come on refreshed, new-added, and encouraged,
From which advantage shall we cut him off
If at Philippi we do face him there,
These people at our back.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Your reasons are good, but I have better reasons for doing the opposite. The people who live between here and Philippi are loyal to us only because we force them to be. We made them contribute to our efforts against their will. The enemy, marching past them, will add them to its numbers, then come at us refreshed, newly reinforced, and full of courage. Thus we must cut him off from this advantage. If we meet him at Philippi, these people will be at our backs.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Hear me, good brother -
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Listen to me, good brother.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Under your pardon. You must note beside,
That we have tried the utmost of our friends,
Our legions are brim-full, our cause is ripe.
The enemy increaseth every day.
We, at the height, are ready to decline.
There is a tide in the affairs of men,
Which, taken at the flood, leads on to fortune;
Omitted, all the voyage of their life
Is bound in shallows and in miseries.
On such a full sea are we now afloat,
And we must take the current when it serves
Or lose our ventures.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Begging your pardon, I'll continue what I was saying. You must also take into account that we've gotten as much from our friends as they can give. Our regiments are full to the brim; our cause is ready.
The enemy gets larger each day. We, now at our largest, can only decrease. There's a tidal movement in men's affairs. Seizing the highest tide leads on to fortune. If high tide is let to pass, all the rest of the voyage of their lives will be marked by difficulty and misery. It's on such a high tide that we're now floating, and we must take the current when it is offered, or lose our campaign.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Then, with your will, go on.
We'll along ourselves, and meet them at Philippi.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
If that's what you want, all right. We'll go forward with you and meet them at Philippi.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
The deep of night is crept upon our talk,
And nature must obey necessity,
Which we will niggard with a little rest.
There is no more to say?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
It's now late at night, and actions must accommodate bodily needs, which we'll satisfy with only a short rest. That's all there is to say.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
No more. Good night.
Early tomorrow will we rise and hence.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
There's nothing else. Good night. We'll rise and leave early tomorrow.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Lucius!
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Lucius!

paragraphs.original:
Enter LUCIUS
LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS enters.
LUCIUS

paragraphs.original: My gown.
paragraphs.translated: My nightgown.

paragraphs.original:
Exit LUCIUS
LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS exits.
LUCIUS

paragraphs.original:
Farewell, good Messala. - 
Good night, Titinius. - Noble, noble Cassius,
Good night and good repose.
paragraphs.translated: Farewell, good Messala. Good night, Titinius. Noble, noble Cassius, good night and sleep well.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
O my dear brother,
This was an ill beginning of the night.
Never come such division 'tween our souls.
Let it not, Brutus.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Oh my dear brother! This was a bad start to the night. Let's pray that we never come into conflict like that again. Let's not, Brutus.

paragraphs.original:
Enter LUCIUS with the gown
LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS enters with the nightgown.
LUCIUS

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Everything is well.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Everything's fine.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Good night, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Good night, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Good night, good brother.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Good night, good brother.

paragraphs.original:
TITINIUS, MESSALA
Good night, Lord Brutus.
paragraphs.translated:
TITINIUS, MESSALA
Good night, Lord Brutus.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Farewell, everyone.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Farewell, everyone.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt CASSIUS, TITINIUS, and MESSALA
CASSIUS
TITINIUS
MESSALA
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS, TITINIUS, and MESSALA exit.
CASSIUS
TITINIUS
MESSALA

paragraphs.original: Give me the gown. Where is thy instrument?
paragraphs.translated: Give me the gown. Where's your lute?

paragraphs.original:
LUCIUS
Here in the tent.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS
Here in the tent.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
What, thou speak'st drowsily?
Poor knave, I blame thee not. Thou art o'erwatched.
Call Claudio and some other of my men.
I'll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
What, are you sleepy? Poor boy, I don't blame you; you've stayed awake too long. Call Claudio and some of my other men. I'll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.

paragraphs.original:
LUCIUS
Varrus and Claudio!
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS
Varrus and Claudio!

paragraphs.original:
Enter VARRUS and CLAUDIO
VARRUS
CLAUDIO
paragraphs.translated:
VARRUS and CLAUDIO enter.
VARRUS
CLAUDIO

paragraphs.original:
VARRUS
Calls my lord?
paragraphs.translated:
VARRUS
Did you call, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
I pray you, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep.
It may be I shall raise you by and by
On business to my brother Cassius.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Sirs, I ask you to sleep in my tent. I might wake you up in a while to send you on an errand to my brother Cassius.

paragraphs.original:
VARRUS
So please you, we will stand and watch your pleasure.
paragraphs.translated:
VARRUS
If you like, we'll stand by and wait to do whatever you need.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
I will not have it so. Lie down, good sirs.
It may be I shall otherwise bethink me.
 - Look, Lucius, here's the book I sought for so.
I put it in the pocket of my gown.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
No, please, lie down, good sirs, because I might change my mind. Look, Lucius, here's the book I was searching for. I put it in the pocket of my nightgown.

paragraphs.original:
VARRUS and CLAUDIO lie down
VARRUS
CLAUDIO
paragraphs.translated:
VARRUS and CLAUDIO lie down.
VARRUS
CLAUDIO

paragraphs.original:
LUCIUS
I was sure your lordship did not give it me.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS
I was sure that you hadn't given it to me.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Bear with me, good boy, I am much forgetful.
Canst thou hold up thy heavy eyes awhile,
And touch thy instrument a strain or two?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Bear with me, good boy. I've become very forgetful. Can you stay awake a bit longer and play a few tunes on your lute?

paragraphs.original:
LUCIUS
Ay, my lord, an 't please you.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS
Yes, my lord, if you would like.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
It does, my boy.
I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
I would, my boy. I ask too much of you, but you're always willing.

paragraphs.original:
LUCIUS
It is my duty, sir.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS
It's my duty, sir.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
I should not urge thy duty past thy might.
I know young bloods look for a time of rest.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
I shouldn't make you do more than you're able. I know that young men look forward to their rest.

paragraphs.original:
LUCIUS
I have slept, my lord, already.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS
I've already slept, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
It was well done, and thou shalt sleep again.
I will not hold thee long. If I do live,
I will be good to thee.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
That was good planning, and you'll sleep some more. I won't keep you very long. If I live through this, I'll be good to you.

paragraphs.original:
LUCIUS plays music and sings a song, falling asleep
LUCIUS
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS plays music and sings a song, then falls asleep.
LUCIUS

paragraphs.original:
This is a sleepy tune. O murderous slumber,
Layst thou thy leaden mace upon my boy
That plays thee music? - Gentle knave, good night.
I will not do thee so much wrong to wake thee.
If thou dost nod, thou break'st thy instrument.
I'll take it from thee. And, good boy, good night.
 - Let me see, let me see. Is not the leaf turned down
Where I left reading? Here it is, I think.
paragraphs.translated: This is a sleepy tune. Oh, deadening sleep, have you taken over my boy who plays music for you? Gentle boy, good night. I won't trouble you so much as to wake you. If you were to droop down, you'd break your instrument, and so I'll take it from you. Good night, good boy. Let me see, let me see. Didn't I turn down the page where I left off reading? Here it is, I think. This candle doesn't give much light.

paragraphs.original:
Enter the GHOST of Caesar
GHOST
paragraphs.translated:
The GHOST of Caesar enters.
GHOST

paragraphs.original:
How ill this taper burns! - Ha, who comes here?
I think it is the weakness of mine eyes
That shapes this monstrous apparition.
It comes upon me. - Art thou any thing?
Art thou some god, some angel, or some devil
That makest my blood cold and my hair to stare?
Speak to me what thou art.
paragraphs.translated: What! Who goes there? I think it's my bad eyesight that's making me see this horrible vision. It's coming toward me. Are you real? Are you a god, an angel, or a devil, that you make my blood turn cold and my hair stand up? Tell me what you are.

paragraphs.original:
GHOST
Thy evil spirit, Brutus.
paragraphs.translated:
GHOST
I'm your evil spirit, Brutus.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Why comest thou?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Why do you come here?

paragraphs.original:
GHOST
To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi.
paragraphs.translated:
GHOST
To tell you that you'll see me at Philippi.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Well, then I shall see thee again?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Then I'll see you again?

paragraphs.original:
GHOST
Ay, at Philippi.
paragraphs.translated:
GHOST
Yes, at Philippi.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Why, I will see thee at Philippi, then.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Alright, then I'll see you at Philippi.

paragraphs.original:
Exit GHOST
GHOST
paragraphs.translated:
The GHOST exits.
GHOST

paragraphs.original:
Now I have taken heart thou vanishest.
Ill spirit, I would hold more talk with thee.
 - Boy, Lucius! - Varrus! - Claudio! - Sirs, awake!
 - Claudio!
paragraphs.translated: Just as you go, I find the courage to talk to you. Evil spirit, I want to talk some more. Boy, Lucius! Varrus! Claudio! Sirs, awake! Claudio!

paragraphs.original:
LUCIUS
The strings, my lord, are false.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS
My lord, the strings are out of tune.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
He thinks he still is at his instrument.
Lucius, awake.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
He thinks he's still playing his instrument. Lucius, wake up!

paragraphs.original:
LUCIUS
My lord?
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS
My lord?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Didst thou dream, Lucius, that thou so criedst out?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Were you dreaming, Lucius? Is that why you cried out?

paragraphs.original:
LUCIUS
My lord, I do not know that I did cry.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS
My lord, I don't think I cried out.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Yes, that thou didst. Didst thou see any thing?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Yes, you did. Did you see anything?

paragraphs.original:
LUCIUS
Nothing, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCIUS
Nothing, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Sleep again, Lucius. - Sirrah Claudio!
(to VARRUS)
(to
)
Fellow thou, awake!
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Go back to sleep, Lucius. Claudio! (to VARRUS) You there, wake up!
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
VARRUS
My lord?
paragraphs.translated:
VARRUS
My lord?

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
My lord?
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
My lord?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Why did you so cry out, sirs, in your sleep?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Why did you cry out in your sleep?

paragraphs.original:
VARRUS, CLAUDIO
Did we, my lord?
paragraphs.translated:
VARRUS, CLAUDIO
Did we, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Ay. Saw you anything?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Yes. Did you see anything?

paragraphs.original:
VARRUS
No, my lord, I saw nothing.
paragraphs.translated:
VARRUS
No, my lord, I didn't see anything.

paragraphs.original:
CLAUDIO
Nor I, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
CLAUDIO
Me neither, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Go and commend me to my brother Cassius.
Bid him set on his powers betimes before,
And we will follow.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Go to my brother Cassius. Order him to advance his forces first thing, and we'll follow.

paragraphs.original:
VARRUS, CLAUDIO
It shall be done, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
VARRUS, CLAUDIO
Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt severally
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits in different directions.

paragraphs.original:
Enter OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, and their army
OCTAVIUS
ANTONY
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS and ANTONY enter with their army.
OCTAVIUS
ANTONY

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
Now, Antony, our hopes are answerèd.
You said the enemy would not come down
But keep the hills and upper regions.
It proves not so. Their battles are at hand.
They mean to warn us at Philippi here,
Answering before we do demand of them.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
Now, Antony, our prayers have been answered. You said the enemy wouldn't come down but keep to the hills and upper regions. It seems not. Their forces are nearby. They intend to challenge us here at Philippi, responding to our challenge before we've even challenged him.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Tut, I am in their bosoms, and I know
Wherefore they do it. They could be content
To visit other places, and come down
With fearful bravery, thinking by this face
To fasten in our thoughts that they have courage.
But 'tis not so.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
I know how they think, and I understand why they're doing this. They really wish they were somewhere else, but they want to descend on us, looking fierce so we'll think they're brave. But they aren't.

paragraphs.original:
Enter a MESSENGER
MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated:
A MESSENGER enters.
MESSENGER

paragraphs.original:
MESSENGER
Prepare you, generals.
The enemy comes on in gallant show.
Their bloody sign of battle is hung out,
And something to be done immediately.
paragraphs.translated:
MESSENGER
Prepare yourselves, generals. The enemy approaches with great display. They show their bloody heralds of battle, and something must be done immediately.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Octavius, lead your battle softly on,
Upon the left hand of the even field.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Octavius, lead your forces slowly out to the left side of the level field.

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
Upon the right hand I. Keep thou the left.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
I'll go to the right side. You stay on the left.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Why do you cross me in this exigent?
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Why are you defying me in this urgent matter?

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
I do not cross you. But I will do so.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
I'm not defying you, but it's what I'm going to do.

paragraphs.original:
March. Drum. Enter BRUTUS, CASSIUS, and their army, including LUCILLIUS, TITINIUS, and MESSALA
BRUTUS
CASSIUS
LUCILLIUS
TITINIUS
MESSALA
paragraphs.translated:
