The sound of soldiers marching, and a drum. BRUTUS and CASSIUS enter with their army, which includes LUCILLIUS, TITINIUS, and MESSALA.
BRUTUS
CASSIUS
LUCILLIUS
TITINIUS
MESSALA

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
They stand and would have parley.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
They've stopped. They want to talk.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Stand fast, Titinius. We must out and talk.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Stay here, Titinius. We have to go out and talk to them.

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
Mark Antony, shall we give sign of battle?
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
Mark Antony, should we give the signal to attack?

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
No, Caesar, we will answer on their charge.
Make forth. The generals would have some words.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
No, Octavius Caesar, we'll respond to their charge. Go forward. The generals want to speak with us.

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
(to his army) Stir not until the signal.
(to his army)
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
(to his army) Don't move until we give the signal.
(to his army)

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Words before blows. Is it so, countrymen?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Words before fighting. Is that how it is, countrymen?

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
Not that we love words better, as you do.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
Not that we love words more than fighting, like you do.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Good words are better than bad strokes, Octavius.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Good words are better than bad strokes, Octavius.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
In your bad strokes, Brutus, you give good words.
Witness the hole you made in Caesar's heart,
Crying "Long live, hail, Caesar!"
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Brutus, you give a nice speech along with your evil strokes. Think of the hole you made in Caesar's heart when you cried, "Long live Caesar! Hail Caesar!"

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Antony,
The posture of your blows are yet unknown.
But for your words, they rob the Hybla bees
And leave them honeyless.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Antony, we don't yet know what kind of blows you can inflict. But your words are as sweet as honey - you've stolen from the bees and left them with nothing.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Not stingless too?
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
I took their stings too, wouldn't you say?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Oh, yes, and soundless too.
For you have stol'n their buzzing, Antony,
And very wisely threat before you sting.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Oh, yes, and you've left them silent too, because you stole their buzzing, Antony. You very wisely warn us before you sting.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Villains, you did not so when your vile daggers
Hacked one another in the sides of Caesar.
You showed your teeth like apes, and fawned like hounds,
And bowed like bondmen, kissing Caesar's feet,
Whilst damnèd Casca, like a cur, behind
Struck Caesar on the neck. O you flatterers!
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Villains, you didn't do even that much when your vile daggers struck each other as they hacked up Caesar's sides. You smiled like apes and fawned like dogs and bowed like servants, kissing Caesar's feet. And all the while, damned Casca, like a dog, struck Caesar on the neck from behind. Oh, you flatterers!

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Flatterers? - Now, Brutus, thank yourself.
This tongue had not offended so today
If Cassius might have ruled.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Flatterers! Now, Brutus, you have only yourself to thank. Antony wouldn't be here to offend us today if you'd listened to me earlier.

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
Come, come, the cause. If arguing make us sweat,
The proof of it will turn to redder drops.
(draws his sword) Look, I draw a sword against conspirators.
(draws his sword)
When think you that the sword goes up again?
Never, till Caesar's three and thirty wounds
Be well avenged, or till another Caesar
Have added slaughter to the sword of traitors.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
Come, come, let's remember why we're here. If arguing makes us sweat, the real trial will turn that water to blood. (he draws his sword) Look: I draw my sword against conspirators. When do you think I'll put it away? Never, until Caesar's thirty-three wounds are well avenged, or until I too have been killed by you.
(he draws his sword)

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Caesar, thou canst not die by traitors' hands
Unless thou bring'st them with thee.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Caesar, you're not going to be killed by a traitor - unless you kill yourself..

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
So I hope.
I was not born to die on Brutus' sword.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
I hope you're right. I wasn't born to die on your sword.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
O, if thou wert the noblest of thy strain,
Young man, thou couldst not die more honorable.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
If you were the noblest of your family, young man, you couldn't die more honorably.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
A peevish schoolboy, worthless of such honor,
Joined with a masker and a reveler!
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
An annoying schoolboy, unworthy of such an honor, joined by a masquerader and a partier!

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Old Cassius still.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Still the same old Cassius!

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
Come, Antony, away. - 
Defiance, traitors, hurl we in your teeth.
If you dare fight today, come to the field.
If not, when you have stomachs.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
Come Antony, let's go. Traitors, we defy you. If you dare to fight today, come to the field. If not, come when you have the courage.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, and their army
OCTAVIUS
ANTONY
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, and their army exit.
OCTAVIUS
ANTONY

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Why, now, blow wind, swell billow, and swim bark!
The storm is up and all is on the hazard.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Now let the wind blow, waves swell, and ships sink! The storm has begun and everything is at stake.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Ho, Lucillius, hark, a word with you.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Lucillius! I'd like a word with you.

paragraphs.original:
LUCILLIUS
(stands forth)
(stands forth)
My lord?
paragraphs.translated:
LUCILLIUS
(coming forward) My lord?
(coming forward)

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS and LUCILLIUS converse apart
BRUTUS
LUCILLIUS
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS and LUCILLIUS converse to the side.
BRUTUS
LUCILLIUS

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Messala!
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Messala!

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
(stands forth)
(stands forth)
What says my general?
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
(coming forward) What is it, my general?
(coming forward)

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Messala,
This is my birthday, as this very day
Was Cassius born. Give me thy hand, Messala.
Be thou my witness that against my will,
As Pompey was, am I compelled to set
Upon one battle all our liberties.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Messala, today is my birthday - I was born on this very day. Give me your hand, Messala.
You'll be my witness that I've been forced, as Pompey was, to wager all of our freedoms on one battle.

paragraphs.original:
You know that I held Epicurus strong
And his opinion. Now I change my mind,
And partly credit things that do presage.
Coming from Sardis, on our former ensign
Two mighty eagles fell, and there they perched,
Gorging and feeding from our soldiers' hands,
Who to Philippi here consorted us.
This morning are they fled away and gone,
And in their steads do ravens, crows, and kites
Fly o'er our heads and downward look on us
As we were sickly prey. Their shadows seem
A canopy most fatal, under which
Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost.
paragraphs.translated: You know that I used to believe in Epicurus and his disregard for omens. I've changed my mind now and partly believe in omens. Traveling from Sardis, two mighty eagles fell on our front flag and perched there, eating from the hands of the soldiers who'd accompanied us to Philippi. This morning, they've flown away and in their place are ravens, crows, and kites, flying over our heads and looking down on us, as though we were sickly prey. Their shadows are like a deadly canopy, under which our army lies, ready to die.

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
Believe not so.
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
Don't believe in this.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
I but believe it partly,
For I am fresh of spirit and resolved
To meet all perils very constantly.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
I only partly believe it, for I'm enthusiastic and resolved to meet all dangers without wavering.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
(returning with LUCILLIUS) Even so, Lucillius.
(returning with
)
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
(returning with LUCILLIUS)  - Right, Lucillius.
(returning with
)

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Now, most noble Brutus,
The gods today stand friendly that we may,
Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age.
But since the affairs of men rest still incertain,
Let's reason with the worst that may befall.
If we do lose this battle, then is this
The very last time we shall speak together.
What are you then determinèd to do?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Now, most noble Brutus, the gods are friendly with us today so that we, who want peace, can live on to old age! But since the affairs of men are always uncertain, let's think about the worst that may happen. If we lose this battle, this is the last time we'll speak to each other. If we lose, what do you plan to do?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Even by the rule of that philosophy
By which I did blame Cato for the death
Which he did give himself (I know not how,
But I do find it cowardly and vile,
For fear of what might fall, so to prevent
The time of life), arming myself with patience
To stay the providence of some high powers
That govern us below.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
By the same principle that made me condemn Cato for committing suicide, I plan to be patient and submit to what the gods decide. I don't know why, but I find it cowardly and vile to kill oneself early to prevent possible suffering later on.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Then if we lose this battle
You are contented to be led in triumph
Thorough the streets of Rome?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Then if we lose this battle, you'll be willing to be led in chains through the streets of Rome?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
No, Cassius, no. Think not, thou noble Roman,
That ever Brutus will go bound to Rome.
He bears too great a mind. But this same day
Must end that work the ides of March begun.
And whether we shall meet again I know not.
Therefore our everlasting farewell take.
Forever and forever farewell, Cassius.
If we do meet again, why, we shall smile.
If not, why then this parting was well made.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
No, Cassius, no. Don't imagine that I'll ever allow myself to return to Rome in chains. My mind is too great for that. But today, the work that March 15th began must end, and I don't know if we'll meet again. Therefore, accept my everlasting farewell. Forever and forever, farewell, Cassius! If we meet again, then we'll smile. If not, then this parting was well done.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Forever and forever farewell, Brutus.
If we do meet again, we'll smile indeed.
If not, 'tis true this parting was well made.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Forever and forever, farewell, Brutus! If we meet again, then we'll smile indeed. If not, it's true, this parting was well done.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Why then, lead on. Oh, that a man might know
The end of this day's business ere it come!
But it sufficeth that the day will end,
And then the end is known. - Come, ho! Away!
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Well, lead on. Oh, I wish I could know what will happen today before it happens! But it's enough to know that the day will end, and then the end will be known. Come! Let's go!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original:
Alarum. Enter BRUTUS and MESSALA
BRUTUS
MESSALA
paragraphs.translated:
Sounds of battle. BRUTUS and MESSALA enter.
BRUTUS
MESSALA

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these bills
Unto the legions on the other side.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these dispatches to our forces on the other side.

paragraphs.original: Low alarum
paragraphs.translated: Faint sounds of battle.

paragraphs.original:
Let them set on at once, for I perceive
But cold demeanor in Octavius' wing,
And sudden push gives them the overthrow.
Ride, ride, Messala. Let them all come down.
paragraphs.translated: They should advance immediately, because I sense Octavius's side is a bit fainthearted right now, and a sudden push would overthrow him. Ride, ride, Messala. Let Cassius's wing mount a surprise attack.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt severally
paragraphs.translated: They exit in opposite directions.

paragraphs.original:
Alarums Enter CASSIUS and TITINIUS
CASSIUS
TITINIUS
paragraphs.translated:
Sounds of battle. CASSIUS and TITINIUS enter.
CASSIUS
TITINIUS

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
O, look, Titinius, look, the villains fly!
Myself have to mine own turned enemy.
This ensign here of mine was turning back.
I slew the coward and did take it from him.
(indicates his standard)
(indicates his standard)
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Oh, look, Titinius, look! Those villains, our soldiers, flee! I've become an enemy to my own soldiers! This standard-bearer here of mine was running away, so I killed him and took the flag from him. (points to his flag)
(points to his flag)

paragraphs.original:
TITINIUS
O Cassius, Brutus gave the word too early,
Who, having some advantage on Octavius,
Took it too eagerly. His soldiers fell to spoil,
Whilst we by Antony are all enclosed.
paragraphs.translated:
TITINIUS
Oh, Cassius, Brutus gave the orders too soon. Having an advantage over Octavius, he took it too eagerly, and his soldiers began looting, and now we're surrounded by Antony's men.

paragraphs.original:
Enter PINDARUS
PINDARUS
paragraphs.translated:
PINDARUS enters.
PINDARUS

paragraphs.original:
PINDARUS
Fly further off, my lord, fly further off.
Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord.
Fly, therefore, noble Cassius, fly far off.
paragraphs.translated:
PINDARUS
Retreat further, my lord, retreat further. Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord. Therefore you must run, noble Cassius.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
This hill is far enough. - Look, look, Titinius.
Are those my tents where I perceive the fire?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
This hill is far enough. Look, look, Titinius. Are those my tents on fire?

paragraphs.original:
TITINIUS
They are, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
TITINIUS
They are, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Titinius, if thou lovest me,
Mount thou my horse, and hide thy spurs in him
Till he have brought thee up to yonder troops
And here again, that I may rest assured
Whether yond troops are friend or enemy.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Titinius, if you love me, get on your horse and spur him on until he's brought you to those troops and back again, so that I can find out whether those troops are friends or enemies.

paragraphs.original:
TITINIUS
I will be here again, even with a thought.
paragraphs.translated:
TITINIUS
I'll be back quicker than you can think a thought.

paragraphs.original:
Exit TITINIUS
TITINIUS
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Go, Pindarus, get higher on that hill.
My sight was ever thick. Regard Titinius,
And tell me what thou notest about the field.
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Go, Pindarus, climb a little higher on this hill. My eyesight has always been bad. Watch Titinius and tell me what you see in the field.

paragraphs.original:
PINDARUS ascends the hill
PINDARUS
paragraphs.translated:
PINDARUS ascends the hill.
PINDARUS

paragraphs.original:
This day I breathed first. Time is come round,
And where I did begin, there shall I end.
My life is run his compass.
(to PINDARUS)    Sirrah, what news?
(to
)

PINDARUS
(above) O my lord!
(above)
paragraphs.translated:
PINDARUS
(above) Oh, my lord!
(above)

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
What news?
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
What news?

paragraphs.original:
PINDARUS
(above) Titinius is enclosèd round about
(above)
With horsemen, that make to him on the spur.
Yet he spurs on. Now they are almost on him.
Now, Titinius. Now some light. Oh, he lights too.
He's ta'en.
paragraphs.translated:
PINDARUS
(above) Titinius is surrounded by horsemen who are quickly approaching him, yet he spurs onward. Now they're almost on him. Now, Titinius! Now some dismount. Oh, he gets down too. He's taken.
(above)

paragraphs.original: Shout within
paragraphs.translated: A shout offstage.

paragraphs.original: And, hark! They shout for joy.
paragraphs.translated: And listen! They shout for joy.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIUS
Come down, behold no more.
Oh, coward that I am, to live so long
To see my best friend ta'en before my face!
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIUS
Come down, look no more. Oh, I'm such a coward for living long enough to see my best friend taken before my eyes!

paragraphs.original:
PINDARUS returns
PINDARUS
paragraphs.translated:
PINDARUS returns.
PINDARUS

paragraphs.original:
Come hither, sirrah.
In Parthia did I take thee prisoner.
And then I swore thee, saving of thy life,
That whatsoever I did bid thee do,
Thou shouldst attempt it. Come now, keep thine oath.
(gives his sword to PINDARUS)
(gives his sword to
)
Now be a free man, and with this good sword
That ran through Caesar's bowels, search this bosom.
Stand not to answer. Here take thou the hilts
And, when my face is covered, as 'tis now,
Guide thou the sword.

PINDARUS stabs CASSIUS
PINDARUS
CASSIUS
paragraphs.translated:
PINDARUS stabs CASSIUS.
PINDARUS
CASSIUS

paragraphs.original:
Caesar, thou art revenged,
Even with the sword that killed thee.
(dies)
(dies)
paragraphs.translated:
Caesar, you are revenged with the very same sword that killed you. (he dies)
(he dies)

paragraphs.original:
PINDARUS
So I am free. Yet would not so have been,
Durst I have done my will. O Cassius,
Far from this country Pindarus shall run,
Where never Roman shall take note of him.
paragraphs.translated:
PINDARUS
So I'm free. But I didn't want to be free like this. Oh, Cassius, I'll run far from this country to where no Romans can find me.

paragraphs.original:
Exit PINDARUS
PINDARUS
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original:
Enter TITINIUS and MESSALA
TITINIUS
MESSALA
paragraphs.translated:
TITINIUS and MESSALA enter.
TITINIUS
MESSALA

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
It is but change, Titinius, for Octavius
Is overthrown by noble Brutus' power,
As Cassius' legions are by Antony.
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
The armies have merely changed places, Titinius, because Octavius has been overthrown by noble Brutus's forces at the very moment that Antony overthrew Cassius's legions.

paragraphs.original:
TITINIUS
These tidings will well comfort Cassius.
paragraphs.translated:
TITINIUS
This news will comfort Cassius.

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
Where did you leave him?
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
Where did you leave him?

paragraphs.original:
TITINIUS
All disconsolate,
With Pindarus his bondman on this hill.
paragraphs.translated:
TITINIUS
On this hill and in despair, with his slave Pindarus.

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
Is not that he that lies upon the ground?
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
Isn't that him on the ground?

paragraphs.original:
TITINIUS
He lies not like the living. O my heart!
paragraphs.translated:
TITINIUS
He doesn't seem to be alive. Oh, my heart!

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
Is not that he?
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
Isn't that him?

paragraphs.original:
TITINIUS
No, this was he, Messala,
But Cassius is no more. O setting sun,
As in thy red rays thou dost sink tonight,
So in his red blood Cassius' day is set.
The sun of Rome is set. Our day is gone.
Clouds, dews, and dangers come! Our deeds are done.
Mistrust of my success hath done this deed.
paragraphs.translated:
TITINIUS
No, it was him, Messala, but Cassius is no more. Just as the sun's rays turn red when it sets, so Cassius has ended his life in a pool of red blood. The sun of Rome has set! Our day is over. Clouds, dew, and dangers approach. We're finished! He didn't believe I would ever return on my mission, and so he killed himself.
was

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
Mistrust of good success hath done this deed.
O hateful error, melancholy's child,
Why dost thou show to the apt thoughts of men
The things that are not? O error, soon conceived,
Thou never comest unto a happy birth
But kill'st the mother that engendered thee!
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
Yes, he killed himself because he thought we'd lost the whole battle. Sadness, which misconstrues reality, gave birth to his errors in thinking - and then destroyed him.

paragraphs.original:
TITINIUS
What, Pindarus! Where art thou, Pindarus?
paragraphs.translated:
TITINIUS
Pindarus! Where are you, Pindarus?

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
Seek him, Titinius, whilst I go to meet
The noble Brutus, thrusting this report
Into his ears. I may say "thrusting" it,
For piercing steel and darts envenomèd
Shall be as welcome to the ears of Brutus
As tidings of this sight.
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
Look for him, Titinius, while I go to meet the noble Brutus and force him to hear this news. I say "force" because Brutus would rather I stuck sharp blades and poisoned arrows in his ears than fill them with this.

paragraphs.original:
TITINIUS
Hie you, Messala,
And I will seek for Pindarus the while.
paragraphs.translated:
TITINIUS
Hurry, Messala, and I'll look for Pindarus in the meantime.

paragraphs.original:
Exit MESSALA
MESSALA
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA exits.
MESSALA

paragraphs.original:
Why didst thou send me forth, brave Cassius?
Did I not meet thy friends? And did not they
Put on my brows this wreath of victory
And bid me give it thee? Didst thou not hear their shouts?
Alas, thou hast misconstrued everything!
But, hold thee, take this garland on thy brow.
Thy Brutus bid me give it thee, and I
Will do his bidding.
(lays wreath on CASSIUS's head) Brutus, come apace,
(lays wreath on
's head)
And see how I regarded Caius Cassius.
 - By your leave, gods, this is a Roman's part.
Come, Cassius' sword, and find Titinius' heart.
(stabs himself with CASSIUS's sword and dies)
(stabs himself with
's sword and dies)
paragraphs.translated:
Why did you send me out, brave Cassius? Didn't I meet up with your allies? And didn't they place the wreath of victory on my brow and order me to give it to you? Didn't you hear their shouts? Alas, you misunderstood everything! But let me place this wreath on your head. Your Brutus ordered me to give it to you, and I'll do what he says. (he lays a wreath on CASSIUS's head) Brutus, come this way and see how much I admired Caius Cassius. With your permission, gods, this is a Roman's duty. Come, Cassius's sword, and strike Titinius's heart. (he stabs himself with CASSIUS's sword and dies.)
(he lays a wreath on
's head)
(he stabs himself with
's sword and dies.)

paragraphs.original:
Alarum. Enter BRUTUS, MESSALA, young CATO, STRATO, VOLUMNIUS, LUCILLIUS, LABIO, and FLAVIO
BRUTUS
MESSALA
CATO
STRATO
VOLUMNIUS
LUCILLIUS
LABIO
FLAVIO
paragraphs.translated:
Sounds of battle. BRUTUS, MESSALA, young CATO, STRATO, VOLUMNIUS, LUCILLIUS, LABIO, and FLAVIO enter.
BRUTUS
MESSALA
CATO
STRATO
VOLUMNIUS
LUCILLIUS
LABIO
FLAVIO

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Where, where, Messala, doth his body lie?
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Where is his body, Messala?

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
Lo, yonder, and Titinius mourning it.
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
Over there, where Titinius mourns it.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Titinius' face is upward.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Titinius is lying face-up.

paragraphs.original:
CATO
He is slain.
paragraphs.translated:
CATO
He's been killed.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
O Julius Caesar, thou art mighty yet!
Thy spirit walks abroad and turns our swords
In our own proper entrails.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Oh, Julius Caesar, you are still powerful. Your ghost walks the earth and turns our swords toward our own stomachs.

paragraphs.original: Low alarums
paragraphs.translated: Faint sounds of battle.

paragraphs.original:
CATO
Brave Titinius! - 
Look whe 'er he have not crowned dead Cassius.
paragraphs.translated:
CATO
Brave Titinius! Look, he even put the crown on dead Cassius!

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Are yet two Romans living such as these?
 - The last of all the Romans, fare thee well!
It is impossible that ever Rome
Should breed thy fellow. - Friends, I owe more tears
To this dead man than you shall see me pay.
 - I shall find time, Cassius, I shall find time.
 - Come, therefore, and to Thasos send his body.
His funerals shall not be in our camp,
Lest it discomfort us. - Lucillius, come. - 
And come, young Cato. Let us to the field.
 - Labio and Flavio, set our battles on.
 - 'Tis three o'clock, and, Romans, yet ere night
We shall try fortune in a second fight.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Could you have found two Romans as good as these two? Good-bye to you, the last of all the Romans. Rome will never produce your equal. Friends, I owe more tears to this dead man than you will see me shed. I will find the time to cry for you, Cassius, I'll find the time. Come, then, and send his body to Thasos. We won't have his funeral at our camp, because it might make us too sad to fight. Lucillius, come. And come, young Cato. Let's proceed to the field. Labio and Flavio, push our armies onward. It is three o'clock, and, Romans, before night, we will try our luck in a second battle.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original:
Alarum. Enter BRUTUS, MESSALA, CATO, LUCILLIUS, and FLAVIO
BRUTUS
MESSALA
CATO
LUCILLIUS
FLAVIO
paragraphs.translated:
Sounds of battle. BRUTUS,MESSALA, CATO, LUCILLIUS, and FLAVIO enter.
BRUTUS
MESSALA
CATO
LUCILLIUS
FLAVIO

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Yet, countrymen, O, yet hold up your heads!
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Keep on, countrymen. Oh, keep your heads up, even now!

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt BRUTUS, MESSALA, and FLAVIO
BRUTUS
MESSALA
FLAVIO
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS, MESSALA, and FLAVIO exit.
BRUTUS
MESSALA
FLAVIO

paragraphs.original:
CATO
What bastard doth not? Who will go with me?
I will proclaim my name about the field.
I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!
A foe to tyrants, and my country's friend.
I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!
paragraphs.translated:
CATO
Who is so low that he wouldn't? Who will advance with me? I will proclaim my name around the field. I am the son of Marcus Cato! An enemy to tyrants and a friend to my country. I am the son of Marcus Cato!

paragraphs.original:
Enter ANTONY and OCTAVIUS' SOLDIERS Fight
ANTONY
OCTAVIUS
SOLDIERS
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY and OCTAVIUS' SOLDIERS enter and fight.
ANTONY
OCTAVIUS
SOLDIERS

paragraphs.original:
LUCILLIUS
And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus, I!
Brutus, my country's friend. Know me for Brutus!
paragraphs.translated:
LUCILLIUS
And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus. Brutus, my country's friend. Know that I am Brutus!

paragraphs.original:
SOLDIERS kill young CATO
SOLDIERS
CATO
paragraphs.translated:
SOLDIERS kill young CATO.
SOLDIERS
CATO

paragraphs.original:
O young and noble Cato, art thou down?
Why, now thou diest as bravely as Titinius,
And mayst be honored, being Cato's son.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, young and noble Cato, have you been slain? Why, you die now as bravely as Titinius. And you, being Cato's son, will be honored.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST SOLDIER
(to LUCILLIUS) Yield, or thou diest.
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST SOLDIER
(to LUCILLIUS ) Surrender or you will die.
(to
)

paragraphs.original:
LUCILLIUS
Only I yield to die.
There is so much that thou wilt kill me straight.
Kill Brutus, and be honored in his death.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCILLIUS
I'd rather die. Here is some money for you to kill me immediately. Kill Brutus and be honored by the killing.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST SOLDIER
We must not. A noble prisoner!
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST SOLDIER
We must not. He is a noble prisoner!

paragraphs.original:
Enter ANTONY
ANTONY
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY enters.
ANTONY

paragraphs.original:
SECOND SOLDIER
Room, ho! Tell Antony Brutus is ta'en.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND SOLDIER
Make room! Tell Antony that Brutus has been taken.

paragraphs.original:
FIRST SOLDIER
I'll tell the news. Here comes the general.
 - Brutus is ta'en, Brutus is ta'en, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST SOLDIER
I'll tell him the news. Oh, here comes the general - Brutus has been caught, Brutus is taken, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
Where is he?
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
Where is he?

paragraphs.original:
LUCILLIUS
Safe, Antony. Brutus is safe enough.
I dare assure thee that no enemy
Shall ever take alive the noble Brutus.
The gods defend him from so great a shame!
When you do find him, or alive or dead,
He will be found like Brutus, like himself.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCILLIUS
He's safe, Antony. I can assure you that no enemy will ever take the noble Brutus alive. The gods protect him from so great a shame! When you do find him, alive or dead, he'll be found on his own terms.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
(to SOLDIERS) This is not Brutus, friend, but, I assure you,
(to
)
A prize no less in worth. Keep this man safe.
Give him all kindness. I had rather have
Such men my friends than enemies. Go on,
And see whether Brutus be alive or dead.
And bring us word unto Octavius' tent
How everything is chanced.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
(to SOLDIERS) This isn't Brutus, friend, but, I assure you, he is a valuable prize. Keep this man safe. Be kind to him. I would rather have such men as friends than enemies. Move on, find out if Brutus is alive or dead, then return to Octavius's tent to tell us what you've learned.
(to
)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt severally
paragraphs.translated: They exit in opposite directions.

paragraphs.original:
Enter BRUTUS, DARDANIUS, CLITUS, STRATO, and VOLUMNIUS
BRUTUS
DARDANIUS
CLITUS
STRATO
VOLUMNIUS
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS, DARDANIUS, CLITUS, STRATO, and VOLUMNIUS enter.
BRUTUS
DARDANIUS
CLITUS
STRATO
VOLUMNIUS

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Come, poor remains of friends, rest on this rock.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Come, last of my friends, rest on this rock.

paragraphs.original:
CLITUS
Statilius showed the torchlight but, my lord,
He came not back. He is or ta'en or slain.
paragraphs.translated:
CLITUS
Statilius waved the torchlight at us, but he hasn't come back. He's been captured or killed.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Sit thee down, Clitus. Slaying is the word.
It is a deed in fashion. Hark thee, Clitus.
(whispers to CLITUS)
(whispers to
)
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Sit down, Clitus. Killed, most likely - it's become a trend. Listen, Clitus. (he whispers to CLITUS)
(he whispers to
)

paragraphs.original:
CLITUS
What, I, my lord? No, not for all the world.
paragraphs.translated:
CLITUS
Who, me, my lord? No, not for all the world.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Peace then! No words.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Silence, then! Don't give it away.

paragraphs.original:
CLITUS
I'll rather kill myself.
paragraphs.translated:
CLITUS
I'd rather kill myself.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Hark thee, Dardanius.
(whispers to DARDANIUS)
(whispers to
)
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Listen, Dardanius. (he whispers to DARDANIUS)
(he whispers to
)

paragraphs.original:
DARDANIUS
Shall I do such a deed?
paragraphs.translated:
DARDANIUS
Would I dare do something like that?

paragraphs.original:
CLITUS
O Dardanius!
paragraphs.translated:
CLITUS
Oh Dardanius!

paragraphs.original:
DARDANIUS
O Clitus!
paragraphs.translated:
DARDANIUS
Oh Clitus!

paragraphs.original:
CLITUS
(aside to DARDANIUS)
(aside to
)
What ill request did Brutus make to thee?
paragraphs.translated:
CLITUS
(speaking so that only DARDANIUS can hear) What awful thing did Brutus ask of you?
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
DARDANIUS
(aside to CLITUS)
(aside to
)
To kill him, Clitus. Look, he meditates.
paragraphs.translated:
DARDANIUS
(speaking so that only CLITUS can hear) To kill him, Clitus. Look, he's meditating on what to do.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
CLITUS
(aside to DARDANIUS) Now is that noble vessel full of grief,
(aside to
)
That it runs over even at his eyes.
paragraphs.translated:
CLITUS
(speaking so that only DARDANIUS can hear) That noble man is so full of grief that it spills out of his eyes.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Come hither, good Volumnius. List a word.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Come here, good Volumnius. Listen a minute.

paragraphs.original:
VOLUMNIUS
What says my lord?
paragraphs.translated:
VOLUMNIUS
What is it, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Why this, Volumnius:
The ghost of Caesar hath appeared to me
Two several times by night. At Sardis once,
And this last night here in Philippi fields.
I know my hour is come.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Just this, Volumnius. The ghost of Caesar has appeared to me at night twice. Once at Sardis and once last night, here in Philippi fields. I know that my hour has come.

paragraphs.original:
VOLUMNIUS
Not so, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
VOLUMNIUS
No, it hasn't, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Nay, I am sure it is, Volumnius.
Thou seest the world, Volumnius, how it goes.
Our enemies have beat us to the pit.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
No, I'm sure it has, Volumnius. You see how the world goes, Volumnius. Our enemies have driven us to the edge of the grave.

paragraphs.original: Low alarums
paragraphs.translated: Faint sounds of battle.

paragraphs.original:
It is more worthy to leap in ourselves
Than tarry till they push us. Good Volumnius,
Thou know'st that we two went to school together.
Even for that our love of old, I prithee,
Hold thou my sword hilts, whilst I run on it.
paragraphs.translated: It's nobler to leap in ourselves than dawdle until they push us. Good Volumnius, you know that we went to school together. For the sake of our old friendship, I ask you, hold my sword handle while I run on it.

paragraphs.original:
VOLUMNIUS
That's not an office for a friend, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
VOLUMNIUS
That's not a job for a friend, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Alarum still
paragraphs.translated: Continued sounds of battle.

paragraphs.original:
CLITUS
Fly, fly, my lord. There is no tarrying here.
paragraphs.translated:
CLITUS
Run, run, my lord. We can't wait here.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Farewell to you. - And you. - And you, Volumnius.
 - Strato, thou hast been all this while asleep.
Farewell to thee too, Strato. - Countrymen,
My heart doth joy that yet in all my life
I found no man but he was true to me.
I shall have glory by this losing day
More than Octavius and Mark Antony
By this vile conquest shall attain unto.
So fare you well at once, for Brutus' tongue
Hath almost ended his life's history.
Night hangs upon mine eyes. My bones would rest,
That have but labored to attain this hour.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Farewell to you, and you, and you, Volumnius. Strato, you've slept this whole time. Farewell to you too, Strato. Countrymen, my heart rejoices that in all my life I knew no men who were untrue to me. I'll have glory in this losing day - more than Octavius and Mark Antony will gain by their foul conquest. So farewell, all, for my tongue has almost finished with its life. I can't see ahead of me. My bones want to rest after helping me up to this hour.

paragraphs.original: Alarum. Cry within "Fly, fly, fly!"
paragraphs.translated: Sounds of battle. Offstage, someone cries, "Run, run, run!"

paragraphs.original:
CLITUS
Fly, my lord, fly.
paragraphs.translated:
CLITUS
Run, my lord, run.

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Hence. I will follow.
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Go on! I'll follow.

paragraphs.original:
Exeunt CLITUS, DARDANIUS, and VOLUMNIUS
CLITUS
DARDANIUS
VOLUMNIUS
paragraphs.translated:
CLITUS, DARDANIUS, and VOLUMNIUS exit.
CLITUS
DARDANIUS
VOLUMNIUS

paragraphs.original:
I prithee, Strato, stay thou by thy lord.
Thou art a fellow of a good respect.
Thy life hath had some smatch of honor in it.
Hold then my sword and turn away thy face
While I do run upon it. Wilt thou, Strato?
paragraphs.translated: I beg you, Strato, stay by me. You're a man with a good reputation. Your life has had honor in it. Then, hold my sword and turn your face away while I run on it. Will you, Strato?

paragraphs.original:
STRATO
Give me your hand first.
(holds BRUTUS' sword) Fare you well, my lord.
(holds
sword)
paragraphs.translated:
STRATO
Give me your hand, first. (holds BRUTUS' sword) Farewell, my lord.
(holds
' sword)

paragraphs.original:
BRUTUS
Farewell, good Strato.
(runs on his sword)    Caesar, now be still.
(runs on his sword)
I killed not thee with half so good a will.
(dies)
(dies)
paragraphs.translated:
BRUTUS
Farewell, good Strato. (runs on his sword) Caesar, you can rest now. I didn't kill you half as willingly. (he dies)
(runs on his sword)
(he dies)

paragraphs.original:
Alarum. Retreat. Enter OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, MESSALA, LUCILLIUS, and the army
OCTAVIUS
ANTONY
MESSALA
LUCILLIUS
paragraphs.translated:
Sounds of battle. Trumpets sound a retreat. OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, MESSALA, and LUCILLIUS enter with the army.
OCTAVIUS
ANTONY
MESSALA
LUCILLIUS

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
What man is that?
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
What man is that?

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
My master's man. - Strato, where is thy master?
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
My master's man. Strato, where's your master?

paragraphs.original:
STRATO
Free from the bondage you are in, Messala.
The conquerors can but make a fire of him.
For Brutus only overcame himself,
And no man else hath honor by his death.
paragraphs.translated:
STRATO
Free from the bondage you are in, Messala. The conquerors can only make a fire of him, because only Brutus triumphed over himself, and no other man gets to triumph in his death.

paragraphs.original:
LUCILLIUS
So Brutus should be found. - I thank thee, Brutus,
That thou hast proved Lucillius' saying true.
paragraphs.translated:
LUCILLIUS
It's fitting that Brutus be found like this. Thank you, Brutus, for proving my prediction true.

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
All that served Brutus, I will entertain them.
 - Fellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me?
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
I'll take all who served Brutus into my service. You, will you join with me?

paragraphs.original:
STRATO
Ay, if Messala will prefer me to you.
paragraphs.translated:
STRATO
Yes, if Messala recommends me to you.

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
Do so, good Messala.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
Do so, good Messala.

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
How died my master, Strato?
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
How did my master die, Strato?

paragraphs.original:
STRATO
I held the sword and he did run on it.
paragraphs.translated:
STRATO
I held the sword and he ran on it.

paragraphs.original:
MESSALA
Octavius, then take him to follow thee,
That did the latest service to my master.
paragraphs.translated:
MESSALA
Then take this man into your service, Octavius, for he did the final service to my master.

paragraphs.original:
ANTONY
This was the noblest Roman of them all.
All the conspirators save only he
Did that they did in envy of great Caesar.
He only in a general honest thought
And common good to all, made one of them.
His life was gentle, and the elements
So mixed in him that Nature might stand up
And say to all the world, "This was a man."
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY
This was the noblest Roman of them all. All the rest of the conspirators acted out of jealousy of great Caesar. Only he acted from honesty and for the general good. His life was gentle, and the elements mixed so well in him that Nature might stand up and say to all the world, "This was a man."

paragraphs.original:
OCTAVIUS
According to his virtue let us use him,
With all respect and rites of burial.
Within my tent his bones tonight shall lie
Most like a soldier, ordered honorably.
So call the field to rest, and let's away
To part the glories of this happy day.
paragraphs.translated:
OCTAVIUS
Let's treat him according to his virtue, with all the respect and rituals of burial. His body will lie in my tent tonight, with the honorable observance that suits a soldier. So order the armies to rest, and let's go home to share the glories of this happy day.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt omnes
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits.
